paragraphs.original:
Enter ORSINO, CURIO, and other lords; Musicians playing
ORSINO
CURIO
paragraphs.translated:
ORSINO, CURIO, and other lords enter with musicians playing for them.
ORSINO
CURIO

paragraphs.original:
ORSINO
If music be the food of love, play on.
Give me excess of it that, surfeiting,
The appetite may sicken, and so die.
That strain again, it had a dying fall.
Oh, it came o'er my ear like the sweet sound,
That breathes upon a bank of violets,
Stealing and giving odor. Enough, no more.
'Tis not so sweet now as it was before.
O spirit of love, how quick and fresh art thou,
That, notwithstanding thy capacity
Receiveth as the sea, nought enters there,
Of what validity and pitch soe'er,
But falls into abatement and low price
Even in a minute. So full of shapes is fancy
That it alone is high fantastical.
paragraphs.translated:
ORSINO
If it's true that music makes people more in love, keep playing. Give me too much of it, so I'll get sick of it and stop loving. Play that part again! It sounded sad. Oh, it sounded like a sweet breeze blowing gently over a bank of violets, taking their scent with it. That's enough. Stop. It doesn't sound as sweet as it did before. Oh, love is so restless! It makes you want everything, but it makes you sick of things a minute later, no matter how good they are. Love is so vivid and fantastical that nothing compares to it.

paragraphs.original:
CURIO
Will you go hunt, my lord?
paragraphs.translated:
CURIO
Do you want to go hunting, my lord?

paragraphs.original:
ORSINO
What, Curio?
paragraphs.translated:
ORSINO
Hunting what, Curio?

paragraphs.original:
CURIO
The hart.
paragraphs.translated:
CURIO
The
hart.
hart

paragraphs.original:
ORSINO
Why, so I do, the noblest that I have.
Oh, when mine eyes did see Olivia first,
Methought she purged the air of pestilence.
That instant was I turned into a hart,
And my desires, like fell and cruel hounds,
E'er since pursue me.
paragraphs.translated:
ORSINO
That's what I'm doing - only it's my heart that's being hunted. Oh, when I first saw Olivia, it seemed like she made the air around her sweeter and purer. In that instant I was transformed into a hart, and my desire for her has hounded me like a pack of vicious dogs.
my

paragraphs.original:
Enter VALENTINE
VALENTINE
paragraphs.translated:
VALENTINE enters.
VALENTINE

paragraphs.original: How now! What news from her?
paragraphs.translated: What's going on? What have you heard from her?

paragraphs.original:
VALENTINE
So please my lord, I might not be admitted,
But from her handmaid do return this answer:
The element itself, till seven years' heat,
Shall not behold her face at ample view,
But like a cloistress, she will veiled walk
And water once a day her chamber round
With eye-offending brine - all this to season
A brother's dead love, which she would keep fresh
And lasting in her sad remembrance.
paragraphs.translated:
VALENTINE
I'm sorry, but they wouldn't let me in. But I got the following answer from her handmaid. Olivia's not going to show her face for the next seven years - not even to the sky itself. Instead, she'll go around veiled like a nun, and once a day she'll water her room with tears. She's doing this out of love for her dead brother, whom she wants to keep fresh in her memory forever.

paragraphs.original:
ORSINO
O, she that hath a heart of that fine frame
To pay this debt of love but to a brother,
How will she love, when the rich golden shaft
Hath killed the flock of all affections else
That live in her, when liver, brain, and heart,
These sovereign thrones, are all supplied, and filled
Her sweet perfections with one self king!
Away before me to sweet beds of flowers.
Love thoughts lie rich when canopied with bowers.
paragraphs.translated:
ORSINO
Oh, if she loves her brother this much, think how she'll love me when I finally win her over and make her forget all her other attachments! Her mind and heart will be ruled by one man alone - me! Take me to the garden. I need a beautiful place to sit and think about love.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original:
Enter VIOLA, a CAPTAIN, and sailors
VIOLA
CAPTAIN
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA, a CAPTAIN, and sailors enter.
VIOLA
CAPTAIN

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
What country, friends, is this?
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
What country is this, friends?

paragraphs.original:
CAPTAIN
This is Illyria, lady.
paragraphs.translated:
CAPTAIN
This is Illyria, lady.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
And what should I do in Illyria?
My brother he is in Elysium.
Perchance he is not drown'd. - What think you, sailors?
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
And what am I supposed to do in Illyria? My brother is in heaven. Or maybe there's a chance he didn't drown. - What do you think, sailors?

paragraphs.original:
CAPTAIN
It is perchance that you yourself were saved.
paragraphs.translated:
CAPTAIN
It was a total fluke that you yourself were saved.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
O, my poor brother! And so perchance may he be.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
Oh, my poor brother! But maybe by some fluke he was saved too.

paragraphs.original:
CAPTAIN
True, madam. And, to comfort you with chance,
Assure yourself, after our ship did split,
When you and those poor number saved with you
Hung on our driving boat, I saw your brother,
Most provident in peril, bind himself,
Courage and hope both teaching him the practice,
To a strong mast that lived upon the sea,
Where, like Arion on the dolphin's back,
I saw him hold acquaintance with the waves
So long as I could see.
paragraphs.translated:
CAPTAIN
It's possible, ma'am. Don't give up yet. When our ship was wrecked and you and a few other survivors were clinging onto our lifeboat, I saw your brother tie himself to a big mast floating in the sea. He was acting resourcefully and courageously in a dangerous situation. For as long as I could see him, he stayed afloat on the waves like
Arion on the dolphin's back.
Arion

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
(giving him money)
(giving him money)
For saying so, there's gold.
Mine own escape unfoldeth to my hope,
Whereto thy speech serves for authority,
The like of him. Know'st thou this country?
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
(giving him money) Thank you for saying that - here's some money to express my gratitude. Since I survived, it's easier for me to imagine he survived too, and what you say gives me a reason to hope for the best. Do you know this area we're in?
(giving him money)

paragraphs.original:
CAPTAIN
Ay, madam, well, for I was bred and born
Not three hours' travel from this very place.
paragraphs.translated:
CAPTAIN
Yes, ma'am, I know it well. I was born and raised less than three hours from here.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
Who governs here?
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
Who's the ruler here?

paragraphs.original:
CAPTAIN
A noble duke, in nature
As in name.
paragraphs.translated:
CAPTAIN
A duke who is noble in name and character.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
What is his name?
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
What's his name?

paragraphs.original:
CAPTAIN
Orsino.
paragraphs.translated:
CAPTAIN
Orsino.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
Orsino. I have heard my father name him.
He was a bachelor then.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
Orsino. I've heard my father mention him. When I first heard about him, he was still a bachelor.

paragraphs.original:
CAPTAIN
And so is now, or was so very late.
For but a month ago I went from hence,
And then 'twas fresh in murmur - as, you know,
What great ones do the less will prattle of - 
That he did seek the love of fair Olivia.
paragraphs.translated:
CAPTAIN
He's still a bachelor, or at least he was a month ago, when I left. But there was a rumor - you know, people always gossip about royalty - that he was in love with the beautiful Olivia.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
What's she?
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
Who's she?

paragraphs.original:
CAPTAIN
A virtuous maid, the daughter of a count
That died some twelvemonth since, then leaving her
In the protection of his son, her brother,
Who shortly also died, for whose dear love,
They say, she hath abjured the company
And sight of men.
paragraphs.translated:
CAPTAIN
A virtuous young woman, the daughter of a count who died last year. Her brother had custody of her for a while, but then he died too. They say she's totally sworn off men now, in memory of her brother.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
Oh, that I served that lady
And might not be delivered to the world,
Till I had made mine own occasion mellow,
What my estate is.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
I wish I could work for that lady! It'd be a good way to hide from the world until the time was right to identify myself.

paragraphs.original:
CAPTAIN
That were hard to compass,
Because she will admit no kind of suit,
No, not the duke's.
paragraphs.translated:
CAPTAIN
That would be hard to do. She won't allow anyone in to see her, not even the duke's messengers.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
There is a fair behavior in thee, captain,
And though that nature with a beauteous wall
Doth oft close in pollution, yet of thee
I will believe thou hast a mind that suits
With this thy fair and outward character.
I prithee - and I'll pay thee bounteously - 
Conceal me what I am, and be my aid
For such disguise as haply shall become
The form of my intent. I'll serve this duke.
Thou shall present me as an eunuch to him.
It may be worth thy pains, for I can sing
And speak to him in many sorts of music
That will allow me very worth his service.
What else may hap to time I will commit.
Only shape thou thy silence to my wit.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
You seem to be a good person, captain, and although people who look beautiful are often corrupt inside, I believe that you have a beautiful mind to go with your good looks and manners. Please - and I'll pay you plenty for this - help me conceal my identity, and find me the right disguise so I can look the way I want. I want to be this Duke's servant. You'll introduce me to him as a eunuch. You won't be wasting your time, because I really can sing and talk to him about many different kinds of music, so he'll be happy to have me in his service. Only time will tell what will happen after that - just please keep quiet about what I'm trying to do.

paragraphs.original:
CAPTAIN
Be you his eunuch, and your mute I'll be.
When my tongue blabs, then let mine eyes not see.
paragraphs.translated:
CAPTAIN
I won't say a word. You can be a eunuch, but I'll be mute. I swear on my life I won't tell your secret.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
I thank thee. Lead me on.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
Thank you. Show me the way.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original:
Enter SIR TOBY BELCH and MARIA
SIR TOBY BELCH
MARIA
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH and MARIA enter.
SIR TOBY BELCH
MARIA

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
What a plague means my niece, to take the death of her brother thus? I am sure care's an enemy to life.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
What's wrong with my niece? Why is she reacting so strangely to her brother's death? Grief is bad for people's health.

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
By my troth, Sir Toby, you must come in earlier o' nights. Your cousin, my lady, takes great exceptions to your ill hours.
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
For God's sake, Sir Toby, you've got to come home earlier at night. My lady Olivia, your niece, disapproves of your late-night partying.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Why, let her except, before excepted.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Well, she can get used to it.

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
Ay, but you must confine yourself within the modest limits of order.
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
Yes, but you need to keep yourself within the limits of order and decency.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Confine? I'll confine myself no finer than I am. These clothes are good enough to drink in, and so be these boots too. An they be not, let them hang themselves in their own straps.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Keep myself? The only thing I'm keeping myself in is the clothes I'm wearing. They're good enough to drink in, and so are these boots. If they aren't, they can go hang themselves by their own laces!

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
That quaffing and drinking will undo you: I heard my lady talk of it yesterday, and of a foolish knight that you brought in one night here to be her wooer.
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
You're going to destroy yourself with all this drinking. Lady Olivia said so yesterday. She also mentioned some stupid knight you brought in one night as a possible husband for her.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Who, Sir Andrew Aguecheek?
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Who, Sir Andrew Aguecheek?

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
Ay, he.
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
Yes, that's the one.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
He's as tall a man as any 's in Illyria.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
He's as
tall as a man in Illyria.
tall

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
What's that to the purpose?
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
What does his height have to do with anything?

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Why, he has three thousand ducats a year.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Why, he has an income of three thousand ducats a year.

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
Ay, but he'll have but a year in all these ducats. He's a very fool and a prodigal.
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
I bet he'll spend his whole inheritance in a year. He's a fool and a spendthrift.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Fie, that you'll say so! He plays o' the viol-de-gamboys, and speaks three or four languages word for word without book, and hath all the good gifts of nature.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
You shouldn't talk about him like that! He plays the violin and speaks three or four languages word for word without a dictionary. He has all of nature's best gifts.

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
He hath indeed, almost natural, for besides that he's a fool, he's a great quarreler, and but that he hath the gift of a coward to allay the gust he hath in quarreling, 'tis thought among the prudent he would quickly have the gift of a grave.
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
Right - he's a natural-born idiot. Besides being a fool, he's argumentative. If he didn't have the coward's gift for backing down from a fight, they say he'd be dead by now.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
By this hand, they are scoundrels and substractors that say so of him. Who are they?
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Anyone who says that is a lying piece of garbage. Who said that?

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
They that add, moreover, he's drunk nightly in your company.
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
The same people who say he gets drunk with you every night.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
With drinking healths to my niece. I'll drink to her as long as there is a passage in my throat and drink in Illyria. He's a coward and a coistrel that will not drink to my niece till his brains turn o' th' toe like a parish top. What, wench! Castiliano vulgo, for here comes Sir Andrew Agueface.
Castiliano vulgo
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
We only drink toasts to my niece. I'll drink to her as long as there's a hole in my throat and booze in Illyria. Anyone who refuses to drink to my niece until his brain spins around like a merry-go-round is scum. But speak of the devil, here comes Sir Andrew Agueface.

paragraphs.original:
Enter SIR ANDREW
SIR ANDREW
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW enters.
SIR ANDREW

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
Sir Toby Belch! How now, Sir Toby Belch!
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
Sir Toby Belch! How are you, Sir Toby Belch?

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Sweet Sir Andrew!
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Sweet Sir Andrew!

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
(to MARIA) Bless you, fair shrew.
(to
)
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
(to MARIA) And hello to you, my little wench.
(to
)

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
And you too, sir.
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
Hello, sir.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Accost, Sir Andrew, accost.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Chat her up, Sir Andrew. Chat her up.

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
What's that?
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
What?

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
My niece's chambermaid.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
This is my niece's maid.

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
Good Mistress Accost, I desire better acquaintance.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
My dear Miss Chat-her-up, I look forward to getting to know you better.

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
My name is Mary, sir.
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
My name is Mary, sir.

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
Good Mistress Mary Accost -
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
Miss Mary Chat-her-up -

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
You mistake, knight. "Accost" is front her, board her, woo her, assail her.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
No, you've got it wrong. When I said "chat her up," I wasn't saying her name. I was telling you to go after her, woo her, confront her.

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
By my troth, I would not undertake her in this company. Is that the meaning of "accost"?
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
Good heavens, I'd never do that with people watching. Is that really what you meant?

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
Fare you well, gentlemen. (she starts to exit)
(she starts to exit)
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
Goodbye, gentlemen. (she starts to exit)
(she starts to exit)

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
An thou let part so, Sir Andrew, would thou mightst never draw sword again.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
She's leaving. If you let her go this easily, Sir Andrew, you don't deserve to ever use your sword again.

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
An you part so, mistress, I would I might never draw sword again. Fair lady, do you think you have fools in hand?
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
If you leave like this, my dear, I won't ever use my sword again. I'm not just talking nonsense to you, I mean everything I say. Do you think you've got a couple of fools on your hands here?

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
Sir, I have not you by the hand.
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
I'm not holding your hand, sir.

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
Marry, but you shall have, and here's my hand.
(he offers her his hand)
(he offers her his hand)
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
But you will. Here's my hand. (he offers her his hand)
(he offers her his hand)

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
(taking his hand) Now, sir, thought is free. I pray you, bring your hand to the buttery-bar and let it drink.
(taking his hand)
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
(taking his hand) A girl's got a right to her opinions. Take your hand to a bar and put a drink in it.
(taking his hand)

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
Wherefore, sweetheart? What's your metaphor?
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
Why, sweetheart? Is there a hidden meaning in this?

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
It's dry, sir.
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
You're not holding a glass. Your hand is
dry, sir.
dry

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
Why, I think so. I am not such an ass, but I can keep my hand dry. But what's your jest?
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
Well, I hope so. I'm not such an idiot that I can't keep my hands dry. But I don't get it - what's the joke?

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
A dry jest, sir.
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
Just a bit of my dry humor, sir.

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
Are you full of them?
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
Are you always so funny?

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
Ay, sir, I have them at my fingers' ends. Marry, now I let go your hand, I am barren.
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
Yes, I've got a handful of jokes. But oops, when I let go of your hand, I let go of the biggest joke of all.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA exits.
MARIA

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
O knight, thou lackest a cup of canary. When did I see thee so put down?
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Sir, you need a drink. When has anyone ever put you down like that.

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
Never in your life, I think, unless you see canary put me down. Methinks sometimes I have no more wit than a Christian or an ordinary man has. But I am a great eater of beef, and I believe that does harm to my wit.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
Never. I've only been that far down when I've drunk myself under the table. Sometimes I think I'm no smarter than average. I eat a lot of red meat, and maybe that makes me stupid.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
No question.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Absolutely.

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
An I thought that, I'd forswear it. I'll ride home tomorrow,
Sir Toby.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
If I really believed that, I'd give up red meat totally. By the way, I'm going home tomorrow, Sir Toby.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Pourquoi, my dear knight?
Pourquoi,
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Pourquoi, my friend?
Pourquoi

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
What is "pourquoi"? Do, or not do? I would I had bestowed that time in the tongues that I have in fencing, dancing, and bear-baiting. O, had I but followed the arts!
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
What does "pourquoi" mean? Does it mean I will or I won't? Oh, I wish I'd spent as much time learning languages as I spent on fencing, dancing, and
bear-baiting! If only I'd taken school more seriously!
"pourquoi"
bear-baiting

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Then hadst thou had an excellent head of hair.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
You'd have a great hairstyle if you had.

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
Why, would that have mended my hair?
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
Why, would that have fixed my hair?

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Past question, for thou seest it will not curl by nature.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Oh, no question - it won't style itself.

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
But it becomes me well enough, does 't not?
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
But my hair looks good anyway, doesn't it?

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Excellent. It hangs like flax on a distaff. And I hope to see a housewife take thee between her legs and spin it off.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
It looks great. It hangs like an old worn-out mop. Some woman should give you syphilis so you go bald.

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
Faith, I'll home tomorrow, Sir Toby. Your niece will not be seen. Or if she be, it's four to one she'll none of me. The count himself here hard by woos her.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
Listen, I'm going home tomorrow, Sir Toby. Your niece is refusing to see anyone, and even if she saw me, ten to one she'd want nothing to do with me. That duke who lives nearby is courting her.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
She'll none o' the count. She'll not match above her degree, neither in estate, years, nor wit. I have heard her swear 't. Tut, there's life in 't, man.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
She's not interested in the duke. She doesn't want to marry anyone of higher social rank than her, or anyone richer, older, or smarter. I've heard her say that. So cheer up, there's still hope for you, man.

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
I'll stay a month longer. I am a fellow o' th' strangest mind i' th' world. I delight in masques and revels sometimes altogether.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
All right, I'll stay another month. Ah, I'm an odd kind of guy. Sometimes all I want to do is see plays and go out dancing.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Art thou good at these kickshawses, knight?
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Are you good at those kinds of things?

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
As any man in Illyria, whatsoever he be, under the degree of my betters. And yet I will not compare with an old man.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
Yes, as good as any man in Illyria, except for the ones who are better at it than I am. I'm not as good as someone who's been dancing for years.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
What is thy excellence in a galliard, knight?
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
How good are you at those fast dances?

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
Faith, I can cut a caper.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
Believe me, I can
cut a caper.
cut a caper

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
And I can cut the mutton to 't.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
And I can cut some meat to go with your
capers.
capers

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
And I think I have the back-trick simply as strong as any man in Illyria.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
And I can do that fancy backward step as well as any man in Illyria.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Wherefore are these things hid? Wherefore have these gifts a curtain before 'em? Are they like to take dust, like Mistress Mall's picture? Why dost thou not go to church in a galliard and come home in a coranto? My very walk should be a jig. I would not so much as make water but in a sink-a-pace. What dost thou mean? Is it a world to hide virtues in? I did think, by the excellent constitution of thy leg, it was formed under the star of a galliard.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Why do you hide these things? Why do you keep these talents behind a curtain? Are they likely to get dusty? Why don't you go off to church dancing one way, and come home dancing another way? If I had your talents, I'd be dancing a jig every time I walked down the street. I wouldn't even pee without dancing a waltz. What are you thinking? Is this the kind of world where we hide our accomplishments? You're a born dancer. Look how shapely your legs are.

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
Ay, 'tis strong, and it does indifferent well in a dun-colored stock. Shall we set about some revels?
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
That's true. They're strong, and they look pretty good in brown tights. Should we throw a little dance party?

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
What shall we do else? Were we not born under Taurus?
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Why not? Weren't we both born under Taurus?

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
Taurus! That's sides and heart.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
Taurus! That governs the torso and heart, doesn't it?

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
No, sir, it is legs and thighs. Let me see the caper. (SIR
(
ANDREW dances) Ha, higher! Ha, ha, excellent!
dances)
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
No, the legs and thighs. Let me see you dance. (SIR ANDREW dances) Ha, higher! Ha, ha, excellent!
(
dances)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original:
Enter VALENTINE and VIOLA in man's attire, as Cesario
VALENTINE
VIOLA
paragraphs.translated:
VALENTINE enters with VIOLA, who is dressed as a young man named Cesario.
VALENTINE
VIOLA

paragraphs.original:
VALENTINE
If the duke continue these favors towards you, Cesario, you are like to be much advanced. He hath known you but three days, and already you are no stranger.
paragraphs.translated:
VALENTINE
If the Duke keeps treating you so well, Cesario, you'll go far. He's only known you for three days, but he's already treating you like a close friend.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
You either fear his humor or my negligence, that you call in question the continuance of his love. Is he inconstant, sir, in his favors?
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
When you wonder whether he'll keep treating me well, it makes me think his mood might change - or else I'll mess up somehow. Do his feelings toward people change suddenly?

paragraphs.original:
VALENTINE
No, believe me.
paragraphs.translated:
VALENTINE
No, not at all.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
I thank you. Here comes the count.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
Thanks for telling me. Here comes the Duke now.

paragraphs.original:
Enter ORSINO, CURIO, and attendants
ORSINO
CURIO
paragraphs.translated:
ORSINO, CURIO, and attendants enter.
ORSINO
CURIO

paragraphs.original:
ORSINO
Who saw Cesario, ho?
paragraphs.translated:
ORSINO
Has anyone seen Cesario?

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
On your attendance, my lord, here.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
I'm right here, my lord, at your service.

paragraphs.original:
ORSINO
(to VIOLA and attendants)
(to
and attendants)
Stand you a while aloof. (to VIOLA) Cesario,
(to
)
Thou know'st no less but all. I have unclasped
To thee the book even of my secret soul.
Therefore, good youth, address thy gait unto her;
Be not denied access, stand at her doors,
And tell them there thy fixed foot shall grow
Till thou have audience.
paragraphs.translated:
ORSINO
(to VIOLA and attendants) We'll need some privacy for a little while. (to VIOLA) Cesario, I want a word with you. You know everything about me. I've told you all the secrets of my soul. So please go to her house; if they don't let you in, plant yourself outside her door and tell them you won't leave until they let you see her.
(to
and attendants)
(to
)

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
Sure, my noble lord,
If she be so abandoned to her sorrow
As it is spoke, she never will admit me.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
But my lord, I'm sure that if she's as depressed as people say, she'll never let me in.

paragraphs.original:
ORSINO
Be clamorous, and leap all civil bounds,
Rather than make unprofited return.
paragraphs.translated:
ORSINO
Be loud and obnoxious. Do whatever it takes, just get the job done.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
Say I do speak with her, my lord, what then?
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
Well, all right, let's say hypothetically that I do get a chance to speak with her, my lord. What do I do then?

paragraphs.original:
ORSINO
O, then unfold the passion of my love,
Surprise her with discourse of my dear faith:
It shall become thee well to act my woes;
She will attend it better in thy youth
Than in a nuncio's of more grave aspect.
paragraphs.translated:
ORSINO
Tell her how passionately I love her. Overwhelm her with examples of how faithful I am. The best thing would be to act out my feelings for her. She'll pay more attention to a young guy like you than to an older, more serious man.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
I think not so, my lord.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
I don't think so, my lord.

paragraphs.original:
ORSINO
Dear lad, believe it.
For they shall yet belie thy happy years
That say thou art a man. Diana's lip
Is not more smooth and rubious. Thy small pipe
Is as the maiden's organ, shrill and sound,
And all is semblative a woman's part.
I know thy constellation is right apt
For this affair. (to CURIO and attendants)
(to
and attendants)
Some four or five attend him.
All, if you will, for I myself am best
When least in company. (to VIOLA) Prosper well in this,
(to
)
And thou shalt live as freely as thy lord,
To call his fortunes thine.
paragraphs.translated:
ORSINO
My boy, it's true. Anyone who says you're a man must not notice how young you are. Your lips are as smooth and red as the goddess Diana's. Your soft voice is like a young girl's, high and clear, and the rest of you is pretty feminine too. I know you're the right person for this job. (to CURIO and attendants) Four or five of you go along with him, or you can all go if you like. I'm most comfortable when I'm alone. (to VIOLA) If you succeed at this assignment, I'll reward you well. My whole fortune will be yours.
(to
and attendants)
(to
)

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
I'll do my best
To woo your lady - (aside) Yet, a barful strife - 
(aside)
Whoe'er I woo, myself would be his wife.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
I'll do my best to make this lady love you. - (to herself) But what a tough task! - I have to go matchmaking for the man I want to marry myself!
 - (to herself)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original:
Enter MARIA and the FOOL
MARIA
FOOL
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA and the
FOOL enter.
MARIA
FOOL

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
Nay, either tell me where thou hast been, or I will not open my lips so wide as a bristle may enter in way of thy excuse. My lady will hang thee for thy absence.
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
No. Either tell me where you've been, or I won't make any excuses for you to Lady Olivia. Lady Olivia will have you executed for not showing up.

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
Let her hang me. He that is well hanged in this world needs to fear no colors.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
So let her execute me. Anyone who's executed doesn't have to be afraid of anything he sees.

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
Make that good.
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
How do you know?

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
He shall see none to fear.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
Well, he'll be dead, so he won't see anything.

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
A good lenten answer. I can tell thee where that saying was born, of "I fear no colors."
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
That's a lame answer. By the way, I know where you get all your brave talk about not being afraid of anything.

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
Where, good Mistress Mary?
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
Where, good Miss Mary?

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
In the wars. And that may you be bold to say in your foolery.
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
From soldiers. But you'll never see the front lines. It's easy for you to talk about bravery, working as a fool in this palace.

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
Well, God give them wisdom that have it. And those that are fools, let them use their talents.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
Well, we all have our special gifts. Some people are born wise; those of us who were meant to be fools should do what they do best.

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
Yet you will be hanged for being so long absent. Or to be turned away, is not that as good as a hanging to you?
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
But still, she's going to kill you for being gone so long. Or at least fire you. And wouldn't that be as bad for you as being killed?

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
Many a good hanging prevents a bad marriage, and, for turning away, let summer bear it out.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
Sometimes getting killed is a good way to avoid getting married. And as for being fired, it's summer, so it won't be that bad to be homeless.

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
You are resolute, then?
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
You've made up your mind, then?

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
Not so, neither, but I am resolved on two points.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
No, but I've made up my mind on two points.

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
That if one break, the other will hold. Or, if both break, your gaskins fall.
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
Ah yes, the two points where your suspenders are attached to your buttons. If one breaks, the other will hold, but if both points break, your pants will fall down.

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
Apt, in good faith, very apt. Well, go thy way. If Sir Toby would leave drinking, thou wert as witty a piece of Eve's flesh as any in Illyria.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
Clever, very clever. Well, go along now. You'd be the funniest person in Illyria… if Sir Toby ever stopped drinking.

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
Peace, you rogue, no more o' that. Here comes my lady.
Make your excuse wisely, you were best.
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
Shut up, you troublemaker, no more of that. Here comes my lady. If you know what's good for you, you'll think up some good excuse for being away so long.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA exits.
MARIA

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
(aside) Wit, an 't be thy will, put me into good fooling! Those wits, that think they have thee, do very oft prove fools. And I, that am sure I lack thee, may pass for a wise man. For what says Quinapalus? "Better a witty fool, than a foolish wit."
(aside)
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
(to himself) Please, let me think of something funny to say now! Smart people who think they're witty often turn out to be fools, but I know I'm not witty, so I might pass for smart. What did that philosopher
Quinapalus say? Ah yes, "A witty fool's better than a foolish wit."
(to himself)
Quinapalus

paragraphs.original:
Enter OLIVIA with MALVOLIO with attendants
OLIVIA
MALVOLIO
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA enters with MALVOLIO and attendants.
OLIVIA
MALVOLIO

paragraphs.original: God bless thee, lady!
paragraphs.translated: Greetings to you, madam!

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Take the fool away.
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Get that fool out of here.

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
Do you not hear, fellows? Take away the lady.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
Didn't you hear her, guys? Get the lady out of here.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Go to, you're a dry fool. I'll no more of you. Besides, you grow dishonest.
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Oh, go away, you're a boring fool. I don't want to have anything to do with you anymore. Besides, you've gotten unreliable.

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
Two faults, madonna, that drink and good counsel will amend. For give the dry fool drink, then is the fool not dry. Bid the dishonest man mend himself. If he mend, he is no longer dishonest. If he cannot, let the botcher mend him. Anything that's mended is but patched. Virtue that transgresses is but patched with sin, and sin that amends is but patched with virtue. If that this simple syllogism will serve, so. If it will not, what remedy? As there is no true cuckold but calamity, so beauty's a flower. The lady bade take away the fool. Therefore, I say again, take her away.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
Madam, those are two character flaws that a little booze and some common sense can fix. If you hand a drink to a sober fool, he won't be thirsty anymore. If you tell a bad man to mend his wicked ways, and he does, he won't be bad anymore. If he cannot, let the tailor mend him. Anything that's mended is only patched up. A good person who does something wrong is only patched up with sin. And a sinner who does something good is only patched up with goodness. If this logic works, that's great. If not, what can you do about it? Since the only real betrayed husband in the world is the one deserted by Lady Luck - because we're all married to her - beauty is a flower. The lady gave orders to take away the fool, so I'm telling you again, take her away.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Sir, I bade them take away you.
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
I told them to take you away.
you

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
Misprision in the highest degree! Lady, Cucullus non facit monachum - that's as much to say as I wear not motley in my brain. Good madonna, give me leave to prove you a fool.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
Oh, what a big mistake! Madam, you can't judge a book by its cover. I mean, I may look like a fool, but my mind's sharp. Please let me prove you're a fool.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Can you do it?
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Can you do that?

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
Dexterously, good madonna.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
Easily, madam.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Make your proof.
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Then go ahead and prove it.

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
I must catechise you for it, madonna. Good my mouse of virtue, answer me.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
I'll have to ask you some questions, madam. Please answer, my good little student.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Well, sir, for want of other idleness, I'll bide your proof.
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
I'm listening to you only because I've got nothing better to do.

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
Good madonna, why mournest thou?
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
My dear madam, why are you in mourning?

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Good fool, for my brother's death.
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
My dear fool, because my brother died.

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
I think his soul is in hell, madonna.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
I think his soul's in hell, my lady.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
I know his soul is in heaven, fool.
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
I know his soul's in heaven, fool.

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
The more fool, madonna, to mourn for your brother's soul being in heaven. Take away the fool, gentlemen.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
Then you're a fool for being sad that your brother's soul is in heaven. Take away this fool, gentlemen.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
What think you of this fool, Malvolio? Doth he not mend?
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
What do you think of this fool, Malvolio? Isn't he getting funnier?

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
Yes, and shall do till the pangs of death shake him. Infirmity, that decays the wise, doth ever make the better fool.
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
Yes, and he'll keep getting funnier till he dies. Old age always makes people act funny - even wise people, but fools more than anybody.

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
God send you, sir, a speedy infirmity, for the better increasing your folly! Sir Toby will be sworn that I am no fox, but he will not pass his word for two pence that you are no fool.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
I hope you go senile soon, sir, so you can become a more foolish fool! Sir Toby would bet a fortune that I'm not smart, but he wouldn't bet two cents that you're not a fool.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
How say you to that, Malvolio?
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
What do you say to that, Malvolio?

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
I marvel your ladyship takes delight in such a barren rascal.
I saw him put down the other day with an ordinary fool that
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
I'm surprised you enjoy the company of this stupid troublemaker. The other day I saw him defeated in a

paragraphs.original: has no more brain than a stone. Look you now, he's out of his guard already. Unless you laugh and minister occasion to him, he is gagged. I protest I take these wise men that crow so at these set kind of fools no better than the fools' zanies.
paragraphs.translated: battle of wits by an ordinary jester with no more brains than a rock. Look at him, he's at a loss for words already. Unless he's got somebody laughing at him, he can't think of anything to say. I swear, anyone smart who laughs at these courts jesters is nothing but a jester's apprentice.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Oh, you are sick of self-love, Malvolio, and taste with a distempered appetite. To be generous, guiltless, and of free disposition is to take those things for bird-bolts that you deem cannon-bullets. There is no slander in an allowed fool, though he do nothing but rail. Nor no railing in a known discreet man, though he do nothing but reprove.
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Malvolio, your vanity is damaging your good taste. If you were generous, innocent, and good-natured, you wouldn't get so upset by what the fool says. You'd think of his wisecracks as harmless little firecrackers, not hurtful bullets. A court jester isn't really criticizing people, even if he does nothing but make fun of them all day long. And a wise person doesn't make fun of people, even if all he does is criticize them.

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
Now Mercury endue thee with leasing, for thou speakest well of fools!
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
You speak so highly of fools! I hope the god of deception rewards you by making you a wonderful liar.

paragraphs.original:
Enter MARIA
MARIA
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA enters.
MARIA

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
Madam, there is at the gate a young gentleman much desires to speak with you.
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
Madam, there's a young gentleman at the gate who really wants to speak to you.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
From the Count Orsino, is it?
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Was he sent by Count Orsino?

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
I know not, madam. 'Tis a fair young man, and well attended.
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
I don't know, madam. He's a good-looking young man, and there are a lot of people with him.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Who of my people hold him in delay?
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Who's talking to him now?

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
Sir Toby, madam, your kinsman.
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
Sir Toby, madam, your relative.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Fetch him off, I pray you. He speaks nothing but madman.
Fie on him!
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Send Toby away, please. He talks nothing but nonsense.

paragraphs.original:
Exit MARIA
MARIA
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA exits.
MARIA

paragraphs.original: Go you, Malvolio. If it be a suit from the count, I am sick, or not at home. What you will, to dismiss it.
paragraphs.translated: Go out and talk to this visitor, Malvolio. If he's got a message from the count, tell him I'm sick, or not home. Tell him anything you want, as long as you make him go away.

paragraphs.original:
Exit MALVOLIO
MALVOLIO
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO exits.
MALVOLIO

paragraphs.original: Now you see, sir, how your fooling grows old, and people dislike it.
paragraphs.translated: Now you see how your fooling gets boring, and people don't like it.

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
Thou hast spoke for us, madonna, as if thy eldest son should be a fool, whose skull Jove cram with brains, for -  here he comes - one of thy kin has a most weak pia mater.
pia mater.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
Madam, you've spoken so highly of us fools, you'd think your oldest son was going into that line of work. I hope God crams his skull full of brains, because here comes one of your relatives who's pretty weak in the head.

paragraphs.original:
Enter SIR TOBY BELCH
SIR TOBY BELCH
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH enters.
SIR TOBY BELCH

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
By mine honor, half-drunk. What is he at the gate, cousin?
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
I swear, he's half drunk already. Who's that at the gate, uncle?

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
A gentleman.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
A gentleman.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
A gentleman? What gentleman?
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
A gentleman? What gentleman?

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
'Tis a gentleman here - a plague o' these pickle herring!
How now, sot!
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
There's some gentleman out there. - (belching) Damn these pickled herring! They upset my stomach. How's it going, fool?
(belching)

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
Good Sir Toby!
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
Good Sir Toby!

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Cousin, cousin, how have you come so early by this lethargy?
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Uncle, uncle, how are you already so brain-dead so early in the day?

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Lechery! I defy lechery. There's one at the gate.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Brain-dead! Nonsense. I defy brain-death! I told you, someone's at the gate.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Ay, marry, what is he?
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Yes, but who is he?

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Let him be the devil, an he will, I care not. Give me faith, say I. Well, it's all one.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Let him be the devil if he wants to, I don't care. God will protect me. What do I care who it is?

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH exits.
SIR TOBY BELCH

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
What's a drunken man like, fool?
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Tell me what a drunk is like, fool.

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
Like a drowned man, a fool and a madman. One draught above heat makes him a fool, the second mads him, and a third drowns him.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
He's a fool, a madman, and a drowned man. The first drink makes him a fool, the second makes him crazy, and the third drowns him.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Go thou and seek the crowner, and let him sit o' my coz. For he's in the third degree of drink, he's drowned. Go look after him.
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Go find the coroner and tell him to perform an inquest on my uncle, because he's in the third degree of drunkenness - he's drowned. Go take care of him.

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
He is but mad yet, madonna, and the fool shall look to the madman.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
He's still only in the crazy phase. The fool will go take care of the madman.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated:
The FOOL exits.
FOOL

paragraphs.original:
Enter MALVOLIO
MALVOLIO
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO enters.
MALVOLIO

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
Madam, yond young fellow swears he will speak with you. I told him you were sick. He takes on him to understand so much, and therefore comes to speak with you. I told him you were asleep. He seems to have a foreknowledge of that too, and therefore comes to speak with you. What is to be said to him, lady? He's fortified against any denial.
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
Madam, that young man out there says he's got to speak to you. I told him you were sick. He claimed he knew that, and that's why he's come to speak with you. I told him you were asleep. He claimed to know that already too, and said that's the reason he's come to speak with you. What can I say to him, lady? He's got an answer for everything.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Tell him he shall not speak with me.
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Tell him he's not going to speak with me.

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
Has been told so, and he says he'll stand at your door like a sheriff's post, and be the supporter to a bench, but he'll speak with you.
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
I told him that. He says he'll stand at your door like a signpost or a bench until he speaks with you.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
What kind o' man is he?
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
What kind of man is he?

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
Why, of mankind.
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
Just a man, like any other.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
What manner of man?
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
But what's he like?

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
Of very ill manner. He'll speak with you, will you or no.
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
He's very rude. He insists he'll speak with you whether you want him to or not.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Of what personage and years is he?
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
What does he look like? How old is he?

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
Not yet old enough for a man, nor young enough for a boy, as a squash is before 'tis a peascod, or a codling when 'tis almost an apple. 'Tis with him in standing water, between boy and man. He is very well-favored, and he speaks very shrewishly. One would think his mother's milk were scarce out of him.
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
Not old enough to be a man, but not young enough to be a boy. He's like a bud before it becomes a pea pod, or like a little green apple before it gets big and ripe. He's somewhere between boy and man. He's very handsome and speaks well, but he's very young. He looks like he just recently stopped breastfeeding.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Let him approach. Call in my gentlewoman.
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Show him in. Call in my maid.

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
Gentlewoman, my lady calls.
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
Maria, our lady wants you.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO exits.
MALVOLIO

paragraphs.original:
Enter MARIA
MARIA
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA enters.
MARIA

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Give me my veil. Come, throw it o'er my face. (OLIVIA puts on a veil) We'll once more hear Orsino's embassy.
(
puts
on a veil)
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Give me my veil. Come, put it over my face. (OLIVIA puts on her veil) We're going to hear Orsino's pleas again.
(
puts on her veil)

paragraphs.original:
Enter VIOLA, with attendants
VIOLA
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA enters, dressed as CESARIO, with attendants.
VIOLA
CESARIO

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
The honorable lady of the house, which is she?
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
Which one of you is the lady of the house?

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Speak to me. I shall answer for her. Your will?
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
You can speak to me. I represent her. What do you want?

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
Most radiant, exquisite and unmatchable beauty - I pray you, tell me if this be the lady of the house, for I never saw her. I would be loath to cast away my speech, for besides that it is excellently well penned, I have taken great pains to con it. Good beauties, let me sustain no scorn. I am very comptible, even to the least sinister usage.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
What stunning, exquisite, and unmatchable beauty - but please, tell me if you're the lady of the house, because I've never seen her. I'd hate to waste my speech on the wrong person, because It's very well written and I spent a lot of time and energy memorizing it. Beautiful ladies, please don't treat me badly. I'm very sensitive, and even the smallest bit of rudeness hurts my feelings.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Whence came you, sir?
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Where do you come from, sir?

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
I can say little more than I have studied, and that question's out of my part. Good gentle one, give me modest assurance if you be the lady of the house, that I may proceed in my speech.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
I'm sorry, but I memorized what I'm supposed to say here today, and that question isn't part of the speech I learned. Please, my lady, just confirm that you're the lady of the house so I can get on with my speech.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Are you a comedian?
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Are you an actor?

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
No, my profound heart. And yet, by the very fangs of malice I swear, I am not that I play. Are you the lady of the house?
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
No, madam. But I swear I'm not the person I'm playing. Are you the lady of the house?

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
If I do not usurp myself, I am.
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
I am, unless I somehow stole this role.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
Most certain, if you are she, you do usurp yourself, for what is yours to bestow is not yours to reserve. But this is from my commission. I will on with my speech in your praise and then show you the heart of my message.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
If you're the lady of the house, then it's true you're stealing your role, because what's yours to give away is not yours to keep for yourself. But that's not part of what I'm supposed to say. I'll go on with my speech praising you, and then I'll get to the point.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Come to what is important in 't. I forgive you the praise.
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Get to the point now. I'll let you get away with skipping the praise.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
Alas, I took great pains to study it, and 'tis poetical.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
That's too bad, because I spent a long time memorizing it, and it's poetic.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
It is the more like to be feigned. I pray you, keep it in. I heard you were saucy at my gates and allowed your approach rather to wonder at you than to hear you. If you be not mad, be gone. If you have reason, be brief. 'Tis not that time of moon with me to make one in so skipping a dialogue.
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
That means it's more likely to be fake. Please, keep it to yourself. I heard you were rude when you were standing outside my gate, and that's the only reason I let you in. I was curious. But I don't necessarily want to listen to you. If you're just insane, then get out of here. If you're in your right mind, get to the point. I've got no patience for lunacy at the moment, and I don't want to waste my time on ridiculous conversations.

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
Will you hoist sail, sir? Here lies your way.
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
Ready to set sail, sir? The door's right here.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
No, good swabber, I am to hull here a little longer. Some mollification for your giant, sweet lady.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
No, this boat's docking here a bit longer, little sailor. - My lady, would you mind asking your giant here to back off a bit?

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Tell me your mind.
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Tell me what you want.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
I am a messenger.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
I have a message to deliver.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Sure, you have some hideous matter to deliver, when the courtesy of it is so fearful. Speak your office.
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
It must be a message about something horrible, since you deliver it so rudely. Tell me what it's about.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
It alone concerns your ear. I bring no overture of war, no taxation of homage. I hold the olive in my hand. My words are as full of peace as matter.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
It's about you. I'm not bringing any declarations of war or demands for cash. I'm coming in peace.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Yet you began rudely. What are you? What would you?
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
But you began so rudely. Who are you? What do you want?

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
The rudeness that hath appeared in me have I learned from my entertainment. What I am and what I would are as secret as maidenhead. To your ears, divinity. To any other's, profanation.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
If I seemed rude, it's because of how badly I was treated when I got here. Who I am and what I want are a secret. You're the only one I can share the secret with. It's sacred, just for you. It's not for anyone else to hear.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Give us the place alone. We will hear this divinity.
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Everyone, please leave us alone for a moment. I've got a "sacred" secret to hear.

paragraphs.original:
Exeunt MARIA and attendants
MARIA
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA and attendants exit.
MARIA

paragraphs.original: Now, sir, what is your text?
paragraphs.translated: Now, sir, what's this holy secret you wanted to tell me?

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
Most sweet lady -
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
Most sweet lady -

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
A comfortable doctrine, and much may be said of it. Where lies your text?
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Oh, "sweet"! It sounds like a nice and gentle kind of faith. Where's the passage of holy scripture that you're basing your sermon on?

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
In Orsino's bosom.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
In Orsino's heart.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
In his bosom? In what chapter of his bosom?
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
In his heart? In what chapter and verse of his heart?

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
To answer by the method, in the first of his heart.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
The table of contents says it's in the first chapter of his heart.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Oh, I have read it. It is heresy. Have you no more to say?
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Oh, I've read that. That's not holy, it's heresy. Do you have anything else to say?

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
Good madam, let me see your face.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
Madam, please let me see your face.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Have you any commission from your lord to negotiate with my face? You are now out of your text. But we will draw the curtain and show you the picture. Look you, sir, such a one I was this present. Is 't not well done?
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Has your lord given you any orders to negotiate with my face? I don't think so. You're overstepping your bounds now. But I'll open the curtain and let you see the picture. Look, sir, this is a portrait of me as I am at this particular moment. It's pretty well done, isn't it?

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA removes her veil
OLIVIA
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA takes off her veil.
OLIVIA

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
Excellently done, if God did all.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
It was done excellently, if it's all-natural, the way God made it.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
'Tis in grain, sir. 'Twill endure wind and weather.
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Oh, it's all-natural, sir. Wind and rain can't wash it off.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
'Tis beauty truly blent, whose red and white
Nature's own sweet and cunning hand laid on.
Lady, you are the cruel'st she alive
If you will lead these graces to the grave
And leave the world no copy.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
That's true beauty. Mother Nature herself painted your skin so white and your lips so red. My lady, you'd be the cruelest woman alive if you let your beauty die with you, with no children to inherit your good looks for future generations to enjoy.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
O, sir, I will not be so hard-hearted. I will give out divers schedules of my beauty. It shall be inventoried, and every particle and utensil labeled to my will: as, item, two lips indifferent red; item, two grey eyes, with lids to them; item, one neck, one chin, and so forth. Were you sent hither to praise me?
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Oh, I'd never be that cruel. I'll definitely do as you say and leave my beauty for the rest of the world to enjoy. I'll write out a detailed inventory of my beauty and label every part. For example - item: two lips, ordinary red. Item: two gray eyes, with lids on them. Item: one neck, one chin, and so on. Anyway, were you sent here just to tell me I'm beautiful?
item
Item
Item

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
I see you what you are, you are too proud.
But, if you were the devil, you are fair.
My lord and master loves you. Oh, such love
Could be but recompensed though you were crowned
The nonpareil of beauty.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
I see what you're like. You're proud. But you'd still be gorgeous even if you were as proud as the devil. My lord loves you. You should return a love as deep as his, even if you're the most beautiful woman in the world.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
How does he love me?
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
How does he love me?

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
With adorations, fertile tears,
With groans that thunder love, with sighs of fire.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
He adores you. He cries and groans and sighs.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Your lord does know my mind. I cannot love him.
Yet I suppose him virtuous, know him noble,
Of great estate, of fresh and stainless youth.
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Your lord knows what I think. I can't love him. I'm sure he's a very nice man. I know he's noble, rich, young, and with a fine reputation. People say he's generous, well educated, and brave, and he's very attractive.
But I just can't love him. He should have resigned himself to that a long time ago.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
If I did love you in my master's flame,
With such a suffering, such a deadly life,
In your denial I would find no sense;
I would not understand it.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
If I loved you as passionately as my master does, and suffered like he does, your rejection would make no sense to me. I wouldn't understand it.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Why, what would you?
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
What would you do about it?

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
Make me a willow cabin at your gate
And call upon my soul within the house.
Write loyal cantons of contemned love
And sing them loud even in the dead of night.
Halloo your name to the reverberate hills
And make the babbling gossip of the air
Cry out "Olivia!" Oh, you should not rest
Between the elements of air and earth,
But you should pity me.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
I'd build myself a sad little cabin near your house, where my soul's imprisoned. From that cabin I'd call out to my soul. I'd write sad songs about unrequited love and sing them loudly in the middle of the night. I'd shout your name to the hills and make the air echo with your name, "Olivia!" Oh, you wouldn't be able to go anywhere without feeling sorry for me.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
You might do much.
What is your parentage?
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Not bad; you might accomplish something. Who are your parents?

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
Above my fortunes, yet my state is well.
I am a gentleman.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
I was born to a higher position than I've got now. But I'm still fairly high-ranking. I'm a gentleman.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Get you to your lord.
I cannot love him. Let him send no more - 
Unless perchance you come to me again
To tell me how he takes it. Fare you well.
I thank you for your pains. Spend this for me.
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Go back to your lord. I can't love him. Tell him not to send any more messengers - unless you feel like coming back to tell me how he took the bad news. Goodbye. Thanks for your trouble. Here's some money for you.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA offers VIOLA money
OLIVIA
VIOLA
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA offers VIOLA money
OLIVIA
VIOLA

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
I am no fee'd post, lady. Keep your purse.
My master, not myself, lacks recompense.
Love make his heart of flint that you shall love,
And let your fervor, like my master's, be
Placed in contempt. Farewell, fair cruelty.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
I'm not a paid messenger, my lady. Keep your money. It's my master who's not getting the reward he deserves, not me. I hope you fall in love with a man whose heart is hard as a rock and who treats your love like a big joke, just like you've done. Goodbye, you beautiful, cruel woman.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA exits.
VIOLA

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
"What is your parentage?"
"Above my fortunes, yet my state is well.
I am a gentleman." I'll be sworn thou art;
Thy tongue, thy face, thy limbs, actions, and spirit,
Do give thee fivefold blazon. Not too fast! Soft, soft!
Unless the master were the man. How now?
Even so quickly may one catch the plague?
Methinks I feel this youth's perfections
With an invisible and subtle stealth
To creep in at mine eyes. Well, let it be. - 
What ho, Malvolio!
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
"Who are your parents?" "I was born to a higher position than I've got now. But I'm still fairly high-ranking. I'm a gentleman." Yes, I'm sure you are. Your way of talking, your face, your body, your behavior, and your sensitive soul all prove you're a gentleman. Ah, no. Calm down, calm down. If only his lord were more like him. How strange I'm feeling! Can someone fall in love this quickly? I can feel this young man's perfection creeping in through my eyes like some kind of disease, slowly and invisibly. Oh, well. - Malvolio! Come here!

paragraphs.original:
Enter MALVOLIO
MALVOLIO
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO enters.
MALVOLIO

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
Here, madam, at your service.
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
At your service, madam.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Run after that same peevish messenger,
The county's man. He left this ring behind him,
Would I or not. Tell him I'll none of it.
OLIVIA hands him a ring
hands him a ring
Desire him not to flatter with his lord,
Nor hold him up with hopes. I am not for him.
If that the youth will come this way tomorrow,
I'll give him reasons for 't. Hie thee, Malvolio.
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Run after that obnoxious messenger, the duke's servant. He insisted on leaving this ring with me whether I wanted it or not. Tell him I want nothing to do with it. (she hands him a ring) Ask him not to encourage Orsino or to get his hopes up. I'm not for him. If that young man comes here again tomorrow, I'll tell him why. Hurry, Malvolio.
(she hands him a ring)

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
Madam, I will.
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
Madam, I will.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO exits.
MALVOLIO

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
I do I know not what and fear to find
Mine eye too great a flatterer for my mind.
Fate, show thy force. Ourselves we do not owe.
What is decreed must be, and be this so.
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
I don't know what I'm doing. I'm afraid I'm not using my head, and I'm falling for his good looks. Fate, do your work. We human beings don't control our own destinies. What is fated to happen must happen. So let it happen!

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA exits.
OLIVIA

paragraphs.original:
Enter ANTONIO and SEBASTIAN
ANTONIO
SEBASTIAN
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONIO and SEBASTIAN enter.
ANTONIO
SEBASTIAN

paragraphs.original:
ANTONIO
Will you stay no longer, nor will you not that I go with you?
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONIO
You won't stay any longer? And you don't want me to come with you?

paragraphs.original:
SEBASTIAN
By your patience, no. My stars shine darkly over me. The malignancy of my fate might perhaps distemper yours. Therefore I shall crave of you your leave that I may bear my evils alone. It were a bad recompense for your love to lay any of them on you.
paragraphs.translated:
SEBASTIAN
No, I'd rather you stayed here. My luck is pretty bad right now, and it might rub off on you. So just let me say goodbye and face the bad stuff alone - otherwise I wouldn't be thanking you very well for all you've done for me.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONIO
Let me yet know of you whither you are bound.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONIO
At least tell me where you're going.

paragraphs.original:
SEBASTIAN
No, sooth, sir. My determinate voyage is mere extravagancy. But I perceive in you so excellent a touch of modesty that you will not extort from me what I am willing to keep in. Therefore it charges me in manners the rather to express myself. You must know of me then, Antonio, my name is Sebastian, which I called Roderigo. My father was that Sebastian of Messaline, whom I know you have heard of. He left behind him myself and a sister, both born in an hour. If the heavens had been pleased, would we had so ended! But you, sir, altered that, for some hour before you took me from the breach of the sea was my sister drowned.
paragraphs.translated:
SEBASTIAN
Honestly, I can't. I'm just wandering, with no particular destination. But I know you'd never force me to tell you things I don't want to, so I should be polite and tell you what I can. My name's Sebastian, though I've been calling myself Roderigo. My father was Sebastian of Messaline. I know you've heard of him. He's dead now. He left behind myself and my twin sister, who was born in the same hour as me. If God had been willing, I wish we had died in the same hour too! But you kept that from happening. An hour before you pulled me out of the breaking waves, my sister drowned.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONIO
Alas the day!
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONIO
How tragic!

paragraphs.original:
SEBASTIAN
A lady, sir, though it was said she much resembled me, was yet of many accounted beautiful. But though I could not with such estimable wonder overfar believe that, yet thus far I will boldly publish her: she bore a mind that envy could not but call fair. She is drowned already, sir, with salt water, though I seem to drown her remembrance again with more.
paragraphs.translated:
SEBASTIAN
Although many people said she looked like me, she was considered beautiful. And though I can't believe everything people said about her beauty, I'll be so bold as to say she had a beautiful mind. Even those who were jealous of her would have to admit that. She's been drowned in salty sea water, and now my salty tears are about to drown her memory all over again.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONIO
Pardon me, sir, your bad entertainment.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONIO
I'm sorry I wasn't a better host for you, sir.

paragraphs.original:
SEBASTIAN
O good Antonio, forgive me your trouble.
paragraphs.translated:
SEBASTIAN
Oh, Antonio, I'm sorry I caused you so much trouble.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONIO
If you will not murder me for my love, let me be your servant.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONIO
I care about you a lot. Please let me be your servant so I can be with you. You'll be killing me if you don't.

paragraphs.original:
SEBASTIAN
If you will not undo what you have done - that is, kill him whom you have recovered - desire it not. Fare you well at once. My bosom is full of kindness, and I am yet so near the manners of my mother, that upon the least occasion more mine eyes will tell tales of me. I am bound to the Count Orsino's court. Farewell.
paragraphs.translated:
SEBASTIAN
If you don't want to break my heart, then say goodbye to me right now. I like you very much. I'm really about to cry, just like my mother would do. I'm going to Count Orsino's court. Goodbye.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated:
SEBASTIAN exits.
SEBASTIAN

paragraphs.original:
ANTONIO
The gentleness of all the gods go with thee!
I have many enemies in Orsino's court,
Else would I very shortly see thee there.
But, come what may, I do adore thee so
That danger shall seem sport, and I will go.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONIO
I wish you all the best. If I didn't have so many enemies in Orsino's court, I'd go join you there. But who cares. I'm so crazy about you that danger doesn't bother me. I'll go anyway.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONIO exits.
ANTONIO

paragraphs.original:
Enter VIOLA, MALVOLIO following
VIOLA
MALVOLIO
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA enters with MALVOLIO following.
VIOLA
MALVOLIO

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
Were not you even now with the Countess Olivia?
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
Excuse me, weren't you with Countess Olivia just now?

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
Even now, sir. On a moderate pace I have since arrived but hither.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
Yes, sir. I've only made it this far since I left her place, walking at a moderate pace.

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
She returns this ring to you, sir. You might have saved me my pains to have taken it away yourself. She adds, moreover, that you should put your lord into a desperate assurance she will none of him. And one thing more, that you be never so hardy to come again in his affairs, unless it be to report your lord's taking of this. Receive it so.
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
She's sending this ring back to you, sir. You should've saved me some trouble and taken it away yourself. She wants you to make it very clear to your lord that she wants nothing to do with him, and that you should never come again on his behalf, unless you want to come back to tell her how he reacted to the bad news. Here, take the ring.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
She took the ring of me. I'll none of it.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
She took that ring from me. I won't take it back.

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
Come, sir, you peevishly threw it to her, and her will is it should be so returned. (he throws down the ring) If it be worth stooping for, there it lies in your eye. If not, be it his that finds it.
(he throws down the ring)
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
You threw it at her rudely, and she wants you to take it back. (he throws down the ring) If it's worth bending over to pick up, there it is on the ground, where you can see it. If not, whoever finds it can have it.
(he throws down the ring)

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO exits.
MALVOLIO

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
I left no ring with her. What means this lady?
Fortune forbid my outside have not charmed her!
She made good view of me, indeed so much
That sure methought her eyes had lost her tongue,
For she did speak in starts distractedly.
She loves me, sure! The cunning of her passion
Invites me in this churlish messenger.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
I didn't give her any ring. What's she trying to say? I hope she doesn't have a crush on me! It's true she looked at me a lot, in fact, she looked at me so much that she seemed distracted, and couldn't really finish her sentences very well. Oh, I really think she loves me! She sent this rude messenger to tell me to come back, instead of coming herself, which would be indis-

paragraphs.original:
None of my lord's ring? Why, he sent her none.
I am the man. If it be so, as 'tis,
Poor lady, she were better love a dream.
Disguise, I see thou art a wickedness,
Wherein the pregnant enemy does much.
How easy is it for the proper false
In women's waxen hearts to set their forms!
Alas, our frailty is the cause, not we,
For such as we are made of, such we be.
How will this fadge? My master loves her dearly,
And I, poor monster, fond as much on him,
And she, mistaken, seems to dote on me.
What will become of this? As I am man,
My state is desperate for my master's love.
As I am woman, now, alas the day,
What thriftless sighs shall poor Olivia breathe!
O time, thou must untangle this, not I.
It is too hard a knot for me to untie!
paragraphs.translated: creet. She doesn't want Orsino's ring! Orsino never sent her a ring. I'm the man she wants. If that's true, which it is, she might as well be in love with a dream, the poor lady. Now I understand why it's bad to wear disguises. Disguises help the devil do his work. It's so easy for a good-looking but deceitful man to make women fall in love with him. It's not our fault - we women are weak. We can't help what we're made of. Ah, how will this all turn out? My lord loves her, and. poor me, I love him just as much. And she's deluded enough to be in love with me. What can possibly fix this situation? I'm pretending to be a man, so my love for the Duke is hopeless. And since I'm a woman - too bad I'm a woman - Olivia's love for me is hopeless as well! Oh, only time can sort out this mess. I can't figure it out by myself!

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA exits.
VIOLA

paragraphs.original:
Enter SIR TOBY BELCH and SIR ANDREW
SIR TOBY BELCH
SIR ANDREW
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH and SIR ANDREW enter.
SIR TOBY BELCH
SIR ANDREW

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Approach, Sir Andrew. Not to be abed after midnight is to be up betimes, and diluculo surgere, thou know'st, - 
diluculo surgere,
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Come on, Sir Andrew. If we're still awake after midnight, then we're up early in the morning. And the doctors say it's healthy to get up early -

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
Nay, my troth, I know not. But I know to be up late is to be up late.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
I don't know what the doctors say. All I know is that staying up late is staying up late.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
A false conclusion. I hate it as an unfilled can. To be up after midnight and to go to bed then, is early, so that to go to bed after midnight is to go to bed betimes. Does not our life consist of the four elements?
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
A false conclusion. I hate your logic as much as I hate an empty drinking cup. Staying up after midnight means that you go to bed after midnight, in the wee hours of the morning, which is early. So it's like going to bed early. Isn't everybody made up of the four elements - earth, water, fire, and air?

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
Faith, so they say, but I think it rather consists of eating and drinking.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
That's what they say, but I think life consists of food and booze.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Thou'rt a scholar. Let us therefore eat and drink. Marian,
I say! A stoup of wine!
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
You're a smart guy. So we should eat and drink. Maria! Bring us some wine!

paragraphs.original:
Enter FOOL
FOOL
paragraphs.translated:
The FOOL enters.
FOOL

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
Here comes the fool, i' faith.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
Look, here comes the fool.

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
How now, my hearts! Did you never see the picture of "We
Three"?
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
Hello, my friends! What a pretty picture, three fools all together.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Welcome, ass. Now let's have a catch.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Hello, you idiot. Sing us a song.

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
By my troth, the fool has an excellent breast.
