I had rather than forty shillings I had such a leg, and so sweet a breath to sing, as the fool has. - (to the FOOL) In sooth, thou wast in very gracious fooling last night when thou spokest of Pigrogromitus, of the Vapians passing the equinoctial of Queubus. 'Twas very good, i' faith. I sent thee sixpence for thy leman. Hadst it?
(to the
)
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
I swear, this fool has an excellent singing voice. I'd give forty shillings to have his nice legs and his beautiful voice. (to the FOOL) Fool, you were very funny last night talking that
astrological nonsense about Pigrogromitus and the Vapians passing the equinox of Queubus. Very amusing. I sent you some money to spend on your girlfriend. Did you get it?
(to the
)
astrological nonsense

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
I did impeticos thy gratillity, for Malvolio's nose is no whipstock. My lady has a white hand, and the Myrmidons are no bottle-ale houses.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
I gave your little present to my girlfriend because you can't get a grip on Malvolio's nose to whip your horse with it. My girlfriend has beautiful white hands, and great warriors aren't
mom-and-pop diners, you know.
mom-and-pop diners

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
Excellent! Why, this is the best fooling when all is done.
Now, a song.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
Ha, ha! I love it when you talk nonsense - that's what fools should do. Come on now, sing for us.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(giving money to the FOOL)
(giving money to the
)
Come on. There is sixpence for you. Let's have a song.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(giving the FOOL money) Yes, come on. Here's sixpence for you. Let's hear a song.
(giving the
money)

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
(giving money to the FOOL)
(giving money to the
)
There's a testril of me too. If one knight give a -
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
(giving the FOOL money) Here's something from me too. If one knight gives - 
(giving the
money)

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
Would you have a love song or a song of good life?
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
Would you rather hear a love song or a song about the good life?

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
A love song, a love song.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
A love song, a love song.

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
Ay, ay. I care not for good life.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
Yes, yes. I'm not interested in being good.

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
(sings)
(sings)
O mistress mine, where are you roaming?
O mistress mine, where are you roaming?
O, stay and hear! Your true love's coming,
O, stay and hear! Your true love's coming,
That can sing both high and low:
That can sing both high and low:
Trip no further, pretty sweeting.
Trip no further, pretty sweeting.
Journeys end in lovers meeting,
Journeys end in lovers meeting,
Every wise man's son doth know.
Every wise man's son doth know.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
(he sings)
(he sings)
Oh my lover, where are you roaming? Stay and listen! Your true love's coming, the one who can sing both high and low: Don't roam any further, pretty darling. Your journey ends when you meet a lover, as every wise man's son knows.
Oh my lover, where are you roaming? Stay and listen! Your true love's coming, the one who can sing both high and low: Don't roam any further, pretty darling. Your journey ends when you meet a lover, as every wise man's son knows.

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
Excellent good, i' faith.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
That was excellent, really excellent.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Good, good.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Good, very good.

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
(sings)
(sings)
What is love? 'Tis not hereafter.
What is love? 'Tis not hereafter.
Present mirth hath present laughter.
Present mirth hath present laughter.
What's to come is still unsure.
What's to come is still unsure.
In delay there lies no plenty.
In delay there lies no plenty.
Then come kiss me, sweet and twenty.
Then come kiss me, sweet and twenty.
Youth's a stuff will not endure.
Youth's a stuff will not endure.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
(singing)
(singing)
What is love? It isn't in the future. When you're having fun now, you're laughing right now. The future's unsure, and there's no reason to waste time. Come kiss me while you're twenty. You won't be young forever.
What is love? It isn't in the future. When you're having fun now, you're laughing right now. The future's unsure, and there's no reason to waste time. Come kiss me while you're twenty. You won't be young forever.

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
A mellifluous voice, as I am true knight.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
A beautiful voice, I swear.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
A contagious breath.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
His breath stinks.

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
Very sweet and contagious, i' faith.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
Yes, it stinks very sweetly.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
To hear by the nose, it is dulcet in contagion. But shall we make the welkin dance indeed? Shall we rouse the night owl in a catch that will draw three souls out of one weaver? Shall we do that?
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
If we could listen to him with our noses, we would definitely say he stinks very sweetly. So what do you say, should we sing loud enough to shake the heavens? Should we sing a round to wake up the night owl? Should we do that?

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
An you love me, let's do 't. I am dog at a catch.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
Let's go for it. I'm a very good singer, and can sing rounds like a
dog.
dog

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
By 'r lady, sir, and some dogs will catch well.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
Then you'll be good at catchy tunes. Dogs like to play catch.

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
Most certain. Let our catch be "Thou Knave."
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
Absolutely. Let's dance to "You Jerk."

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
"Hold thy peace, thou knave," knight? I shall be constrained in 't to call thee knave, knight.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
You mean, "Shut up, you jerk"? That's the song where the singers call each other jerks, right? So I'll be forced to call you a jerk, Sir Andrew.

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
'Tis not the first time I have constrained one to call me
"knave." Begin, Fool. It begins "Hold thy peace."
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
It won't be the first time someone was forced to call me that. You start, Fool. It starts, "Shut up."

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
I shall never begin if I hold my peace.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
I'll never be able to start if I shut up.

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
Good, i' faith. Come, begin.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
That's true. But come on, start.

paragraphs.original: Catch sung
paragraphs.translated: They sing.

paragraphs.original:
Enter MARIA
MARIA
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA enters.
MARIA

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
What a caterwauling do you keep here! If my lady have not called up her steward Malvolio and bid him turn you out of doors, never trust me.
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
You're making a terrible racket out here! Lady Olivia told her servant Malvolio to kick you out of the house. I swear it's true.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
My lady's a Cataian. We are politicians, Malvolio's a Peg- a-Ramsey, and (sings) Three merry men be we. - Am not I consanguineous? Am I not of her blood? Tillyvally! "Lady"! (sings) There dwelt a man in Babylon, lady, lady!
sings) There dwelt a man in Babylon, lady, lady!
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Lady Olivia can go to China for all I care. We're very smart guys, and Malvolio's Little Bo Peep. (he sings) We're just having some fun. - Aren't I her relative, after all? Aren't we related? Fiddle-dee-dee, "Lady!" (singing) There lived a man in Babylon, lady, lady!
(he sings) We're just having some fun.
(singing) There lived a man in Babylon, lady, lady!

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
Beshrew me, the knight's in admirable fooling.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
Gosh, the knight's very good at acting like a fool.

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
Ay, he does well enough if he be disposed, and so do I too.
He does it with a better grace, but I do it more natural.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
Yes, he's good at it when he's in the mood, and so am I. He's practiced more, but it comes more naturally to me.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(sings) O' the twelfth day of December - 
(sings) O' the twelfth day of December -
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(he sings) On the twelfth day of December - 
(he sings) On the twelfth day of December -

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
For the love o' God, peace!
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
For God's sake, shut up!

paragraphs.original:
Enter MALVOLIO
MALVOLIO
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO enters.
MALVOLIO

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
My masters, are you mad? Or what are you? Have you no wit, manners, nor honesty but to gabble like tinkers at this time of night? Do you make an alehouse of my lady's house, that you squeak out your coziers' catches without any mitigation or remorse of voice? Is there no respect of place, persons, nor time in you?
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
Are you all crazy? What's wrong with you? Are you making all this noise at this time of night because you have no manners, or because you're just stupid? Are you trying to turn my mistress's house into a noisy bar? Is that why you're squealing out these ridiculous vulgar songs without lowering your voices at all? Don't you have any respect for anything?

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
We did keep time, sir, in our catches. Sneck up!
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
We respected the beat of the song, sir. So shut up!

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
Sir Toby, I must be round with you. My lady bade me tell you, that, though she harbors you as her kinsman, she's nothing allied to your disorders. If you can separate yourself and your misdemeanors, you are welcome to the house. If not, an it would please you to take leave of her, she is very willing to bid you farewell.
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
Sir Toby, I've got to be frank with you. My lady told me to tell you that while she lets you stay at her house because you're a relative, she doesn't approve of your behavior. If you can shape up, you're welcome to stay in the house. If you can't, and would prefer to leave, she's very willing to say goodbye to you.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(sings) Farewell, dear heart, since I must needs be gone.
(sings) Farewell, dear heart, since I must needs be gone.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(he
sings ) Goodnight, sweetheart, I'm going to leave you now.
(he
sings



) Goodnight, sweetheart, I'm going to leave you now.

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
Nay, good Sir Toby.
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
No, good Sir Toby.

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
(sings) His eyes do show his days are almost done.
sings
His eyes do show his days are almost done.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
(singing) You can tell from his eyes that his life is almost over.
(singing) You can tell from his eyes that his life is almost over.

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
Is 't even so?
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
Is this how it's going to be?

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(sings) But I will never die.
sings
But I will never die.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(singing) But I will never die.
(singing) But I will never die.

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
(sings) Sir Toby, there you lie.
sings
Sir Toby, there you lie.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
(singing) Sir Toby, that's a lie.
(singing) Sir Toby, that's a lie.

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
This is much credit to you.
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
This behavior really makes you look great.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(sings) Shall I bid him go?
(sings) Shall I bid him go?
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(singing) Should I tell him to go?
(singing) Should I tell him to go?

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
(sings) What an if you do?
(sings) What an if you do?
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
(singing) What if y,ou do?
(singing) What if y,ou do?

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(sings) Shall I bid him go, and spare not?
(sings) Shall I bid him go, and spare not?
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(singing) Should I tell him to go, and be harsh with him?
(singing) Should I tell him to go, and be harsh with him?

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
(sings) O no, no, no, no, you dare not.
(sings) O no, no, no, no, you dare not.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
(singing) Oh no, no, no, no, don't you dare.
(singing) Oh no, no, no, no, don't you dare.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Out o' tune, sir. You lie. Art any more than a steward? Dost thou think, because thou art virtuous, there shall be no more cakes and ale?
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
That's out of tune, sir. You lie. (to MALVOLIO) You're nothing more than a servant here. Do you think that just because you're a goody two shoes, no one else can enjoy himself?
to

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
Yes, by Saint Anne, and ginger shall be hot i' the mouth too.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
They certainly will. They'll have double helpings, too.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Thou'rt i' the right. Go, sir, rub your chain with crumbs. A stoup of wine, Maria!
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
You're right. (to MALVOLIO) Go polish your steward's chain, sir. Maria, bring us some wine!
(to
)

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
Mistress Mary, if you prized my lady's favor at anything more than contempt, you would not give means for this uncivil rule. She shall know of it, by this hand.
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
Miss Mary, if you cared what Lady Olivia thinks about you at all, you wouldn't contribute to this rude behavior. I assure you, she'll find out about this.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO exits.
MALVOLIO

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
Go shake your ears!
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
Go and wiggle your ears!

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
'Twere as good a deed as to drink when a man's a-hungry, to challenge him the field and then to break promise with him and make a fool of him.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
There's nothing I'd love more than to make a fool out of that guy somehow. I could challenge him to a duel and then not show up. That would do the trick.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Do 't, knight. I'll write thee a challenge. Or I'll deliver thy indignation to him by word of mouth.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Do that. I'll write a letter challenging him to a duel on your behalf. Or I'll deliver your insults to his face.

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
Sweet Sir Toby, be patient for tonight. Since the youth of the count's was today with thy lady, she is much out of quiet. For Monsieur Malvolio, let me alone with him. If I do not gull him into a nayword and make him a common recreation, do not think I have wit enough to lie straight in my bed. I know I can do it.
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
Dear Sir Toby, don't do anything rash tonight. Ever since the Duke's messenger visited Olivia, she's been upset. As for Monsieur Malvolio, let me take care of him. I'll make a big fool out of him, just trust me. I'll make him famous for his stupidity. Everyone will laugh at him. I know I can do it.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Possess us, possess us, tell us something of him.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Tell us something about him. Come on, tell us something.

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
Marry, sir, sometimes he is a kind of puritan.
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
Well, sometimes he acts like a goody two shoes.

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
O, if I thought that, I'd beat him like a dog!
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
Oh, I'll beat him up for that!

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
What, for being a puritan? Thy exquisite reason, dear knight?
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
You're going to beat him up for being good? And what's your brilliant reason for that, please?

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
I have no exquisite reason for 't, but I have reason good enough.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
I don't have any "brilliant" reason for it, but I have a good enough reason.

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
The devil a puritan that he is, or anything constantly, but a time-pleaser; an affectioned ass that cons state without book and utters it by great swarths; the best persuaded of himself, so crammed, as he thinks, with excellencies, that it is his grounds of faith that all that look on him love him. And on that vice in him will my revenge find notable cause to work.
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
He isn't really that pure and good. He's just a conceited flatterer. He's a pretentious guy who aspires to speak and act like nobility. He's proud, and he thinks he's so stuffed full of wonderful qualities that everyone loves him. That's the weakness I'll use to get revenge on him.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
What wilt thou do?
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
What are you going to do?

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
I will drop in his way some obscure epistles of love, wherein by the color of his beard, the shape of his leg, the manner of his gait, the expressure of his eye, forehead, and complexion,he shall find himself most feelingly personated.
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
I'll drop some mysterious love letters in his path. He'll think they're addressed to him, because they'll describe the color of his beard, the shape of his legs, the way he walks, and the expression on his face. I can make my handwriting look just like Lady Olivia's: she

paragraphs.original: I can write very like my lady your niece: on a forgotten matter we can hardly make distinction of our hands.
paragraphs.translated: and I can't tell the difference between each other's handwriting.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Excellent! I smell a device.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Excellent! Sounds like you've got a good trick in mind.

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
I have 't in my nose too.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
I like it too.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
He shall think, by the letters that thou wilt drop, that they come from my niece, and that she's in love with him.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
He'll think these letters are from Olivia and that she's in love with him.

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
My purpose is, indeed, a horse of that color.
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
Yes, that's the idea.

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
And your horse now would make him an ass.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
He's going to look like a total idiot.

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
Ass, I doubt not.
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
Absolutely, you idiot.

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
Oh, 'twill be admirable!
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
This is going to be great!

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
Sport royal, I warrant you. I know my physic will work with him. I will plant you two, and let the fool make a third, where he shall find the letter. Observe his construction of it. For this night, to bed, and dream on the event. Farewell.
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
It's going to be fun, I promise. I know my medicine will work on him. I'll have you two hide - and the fool too - right where he'll find the letter. Watch his reaction. Meanwhile, let's go to bed and dream about this. Good night.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA exits.
MARIA

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Good night, Penthesilea.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Good night, you amazing woman, you.

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
Before me, she's a good wench.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
She's a fine woman, all right.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
She's a beagle, true-bred, and one that adores me. What o' that?
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
She's a good little woman, and she adores me. What about it?

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
I was adored once too.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
Someone adored me once, too.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Let's to bed, knight. Thou hadst need send for more money.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Let's go to bed, knight. Tomorrow you need to get more money sent to you.

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
If I cannot recover your niece, I am a foul way out.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
If I can't persuade your niece to marry me, I'm going to be in some serious financial trouble.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Send for money, knight. If thou hast her not i' the end, call me "Cut."
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Get your hands on some money and everything will be all right. I know you'll win over Olivia in the end.

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
If I do not, never trust me, take it how you will.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
I know I will too, if it's the last thing I do.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Come, come, I'll go burn some sack. 'Tis too late to go to bed now. Come, knight. Come, knight.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Come on, I'll go warm up a nice glass of sherry for us. It's too late to go to bed now. Come on, my friend, come on.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original:
Enter ORSINO, VIOLA, CURIO, and others
ORSINO
VIOLA
CURIO
paragraphs.translated:
ORSINO, VIOLA, CURIO, and others enter.
ORSINO
VIOLA
CURIO

paragraphs.original:
ORSINO
Give me some music. (music plays)
music plays
Now, good morrow, friends. - 
Now, good Cesario, but that piece of song,
That old and antique song we heard last night.
Methought it did relieve my passion much,
More than light airs and recollected terms
Of these most brisk and giddy-paced times:
Come, but one verse.
paragraphs.translated:
ORSINO
Play me some music. (music plays) Good morning, my friends. - Have them sing me that song again, Cesario, that old-fashioned song someone sang last night. It made me feel better and took my mind off my troubles much better than the silly songs they sing nowadays. Please, have them sing just one verse.
(music plays)

paragraphs.original:
CURIO
He is not here, so please your lordship, that should sing it.
paragraphs.translated:
CURIO
Sir, the person who should sing that song isn't here.

paragraphs.original:
ORSINO
Who was it?
paragraphs.translated:
ORSINO
Who was it?

paragraphs.original:
CURIO
Feste, the jester, my lord, a fool that the lady Olivia's father took much delight in. He is about the house.
paragraphs.translated:
CURIO
Feste, the jester, my lord. Olivia's father used to like him. He's somewhere else in the house.

paragraphs.original:
ORSINO
Seek him out, and play the tune the while.
paragraphs.translated:
ORSINO
Then go find him. Meanwhile, play the tune.

paragraphs.original:
Exit CURIO. Music plays
CURIO
paragraphs.translated:
CURIO exits. Music plays.
CURIO

paragraphs.original:
(to VIOLA) Come hither, boy. If ever thou shalt love,
to
)
In the sweet pangs of it remember me;
For such as I am, all true lovers are,
Unstaid and skittish in all motions else
Save in the constant image of the creature
That is beloved. How dost thou like this tune?

VIOLA
It gives a very echo to the seat
Where Love is throned.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
It really makes you feel what a lover feels.

paragraphs.original:
ORSINO
Thou dost speak masterly.
My life upon 't, young though thou art, thine eye
Hath stay'd upon some favor that it loves.
Hath it not, boy?
paragraphs.translated:
ORSINO
You're absolutely right. I'd bet my life that, as young as you are, you've fallen in love with someone. Haven't you, boy?

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
A little, by your favor.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
A little bit.

paragraphs.original:
ORSINO
What kind of woman is't?
paragraphs.translated:
ORSINO
What kind of woman is she?

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
Of your complexion.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
She's a lot like you.

paragraphs.original:
ORSINO
She is not worth thee, then. What years, i' faith?
paragraphs.translated:
ORSINO
She's not good enough for you, then. How old is she?

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
About your years, my lord.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
About as old as you are, my lord.

paragraphs.original:
ORSINO
Too old by heaven. Let still the woman take
An elder than herself. So wears she to him,
So sways she level in her husband's heart.
For, boy, however we do praise ourselves,
Our fancies are more giddy and unfirm,
More longing, wavering, sooner lost and worn,
Than women's are.
paragraphs.translated:
ORSINO
That's definitely too old. A woman should always pick an older man. That way she'll adjust herself to what her husband wants, and the husband will be happy and faithful to her. Because however much we like to brag, boy, the truth is that we men change our minds a lot more than women do, and our desires come and go a lot faster than theirs.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
I think it well, my lord.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
I think you're right, sir.

paragraphs.original:
ORSINO
Then let thy love be younger than thyself,
Or thy affection cannot hold the bent.
For women are as roses, whose fair flower
Being once displayed, doth fall that very hour.
paragraphs.translated:
ORSINO
So find someone younger to love, or you won't be able to maintain your feelings. Women are like roses: the moment their beauty is in full bloom, it's about to decay.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
And so they are. Alas, that they are so,
To die even when they to perfection grow!
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
That's true. It's too bad their beauty fades right when it reaches perfection!

paragraphs.original:
Enter CURIO and FOOL
CURIO
FOOL
paragraphs.translated:
CURIO and the FOOL enter.
CURIO
FOOL

paragraphs.original:
ORSINO
O, fellow, come, the song we had last night. - 
Mark it, Cesario, it is old and plain;
The spinsters and the knitters in the sun
And the free maids that weave their thread with bones
Do use to chant it. It is silly sooth,
And dallies with the innocence of love,
Like the old age.
paragraphs.translated:
ORSINO
My friend, sing us the song you sang last night. - Listen to it carefully, Cesario, it's a simple old song. Spinners and knitters used to sing it while they sewed, and maidens used to sing it over their weaving. It tells the simple truth about innocent love, as it was in the good old days.

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
Are you ready, sir?
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
Are you ready, sir?

paragraphs.original:
ORSINO
Ay; prithee, sing.
paragraphs.translated:
ORSINO
Yes. Please, sing.

paragraphs.original: Music
paragraphs.translated: Music plays.

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
(sings)
(sings)
Come away, come away, death,
Come away, come away, death,
And in sad cypress let me be laid.
And in sad cypress let me be laid.
Fly away, fly away breath,
Fly away, fly away breath,
I am slain by a fair cruel maid.
I am slain by a fair cruel maid.
My shroud of white, stuck all with yew,
My shroud of white, stuck all with yew,
O, prepare it!
O, prepare it!
My part of death, no one so true
My part of death, no one so true
Did share it.
Did share it.
Not a flower, not a flower sweet
Not a flower, not a flower sweet
On my black coffin let there be strown.
On my black coffin let there be strown.
Not a friend, not a friend greet
Not a friend, not a friend greet
My poor corpse, where my bones shall be thrown.
My poor corpse, where my bones shall be thrown.
A thousand thousand sighs to save,
A thousand thousand sighs to save,
Lay me, O, where
Lay me, O, where
Sad true lover never find my grave,
Sad true lover never find my grave,
To weep there!
To weep there!
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
(he sings)
(he sings)
Come on, let me die now
Come on, let me die now
And put my body in a dark coffin.
And put my body in a dark coffin.
I feel my breath leaving me.
I feel my breath leaving me.
I've been killed by a beautiful girl.
I've been killed by a beautiful girl.
Prepare my shroud of white,
Prepare my shroud of white,
Adorned with sprigs of yew-tree.
Adorned with sprigs of yew-tree.
I'm the most faithful person
I'm the most faithful person
Who ever lived or died.
Who ever lived or died.
Don't scatter sweet flowers
Don't scatter sweet flowers
On my black coffin.
On my black coffin.
Don't let my friends
Don't let my friends
See my poor corpse.
See my poor corpse.
I don't want to hear sad sighs,
I don't want to hear sad sighs,
So bury me where no sad lovers
So bury me where no sad lovers
can find my grave to weep over it!
can find my grave to weep over it!

paragraphs.original:
ORSINO
(giving money) There's for thy pains.
(giving money)
paragraphs.translated:
ORSINO
(giving the FOOL money) Here's some money for your trouble.
(giving the
money)

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
No pains, sir. I take pleasure in singing, sir.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
No trouble, sir. I like singing.

paragraphs.original:
ORSINO
I'll pay thy pleasure then.
paragraphs.translated:
ORSINO
Then I'll pay you for doing what you like.

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
Truly, sir, and pleasure will be paid, one time or another.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
Well, in that case, all right. We all pay for what we like sooner or later.

paragraphs.original:
ORSINO
Give me now leave to leave thee.
paragraphs.translated:
ORSINO
You may leave.

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
Now, the melancholy god protect thee, and the tailor make thy doublet of changeable taffeta, for thy mind is a very opal. I would have men of such constancy put to sea, that their business might be everything and their intent everywhere, for that's it that always makes a good voyage of nothing. Farewell.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
I'll pray for the god of sadness to protect you, sir. And I hope your tailor will make you an outfit out of fabric that changes color, because your mind is like an opal that changes colors constantly. Men as wonderfully changeable as you are should all go drifting on the sea, where they can do whatever comes their way, and go wherever the current takes them. Those are the men whose trips are always successful. Goodbye.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated:
The FOOL exits.
FOOL

paragraphs.original:
ORSINO
Let all the rest give place.
paragraphs.translated:
ORSINO
All the rest of you can leave too.

paragraphs.original:
CURIO and attendants retire
CURIO
paragraphs.translated:
CURIO and attendants retire.
CURIO

paragraphs.original:
Once more, Cesario,
Get thee to yond same sovereign cruelty.
Tell her my love, more noble than the world,
Prizes not quantity of dirty lands;
The parts that fortune hath bestowed upon her,
Tell her, I hold as giddily as fortune;
But 'tis that miracle and queen of gems
That nature pranks her in attracts my soul.
paragraphs.translated: Cesario, go visit that cruel Olivia one more time. Tell her my love is purer than anything else in the whole world, and has nothing to do with her property. The wealth she's inherited isn't what makes me value her. It's her rich, jewel-like beauty that attracts me.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
But if she cannot love you, sir?
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
But if she can't love you, sir?

paragraphs.original:
ORSINO
I cannot be so answer'd.
paragraphs.translated:
ORSINO
I refuse to accept that.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
Sooth, but you must.
Say that some lady, as perhaps there is,
Hath for your love a great a pang of heart
As you have for Olivia. You cannot love her.
You tell her so. Must she not then be answered?
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
But you have to. Just imagine some lady might exist who loves you as powerfully and agonizingly as you love Olivia. But you can't love her, and you tell her so. Shouldn't she just accept that?

paragraphs.original:
ORSINO
There is no woman's sides
Can bide the beating of so strong a passion
As love doth give my heart. No woman's heart
So big, to hold so much. They lack retention.
Alas, their love may be called appetite,
No motion of the liver, but the palate,
That suffer surfeit, cloyment, and revolt;
But mine is all as hungry as the sea,
And can digest as much. Make no compare
Between that love a woman can bear me
And that I owe Olivia.
paragraphs.translated:
ORSINO
No woman is strong enough to put up with the kind of intense passion I feel. No woman's heart is big enough to hold all my love. Women don't feel love like that - love is as shallow as appetite for them. It has nothing to do with their hearts, just their sense of taste. They eat too much and get indigestion and nausea. But my love's different. It's as all-consuming and insatiable as the sea, and it can swallow as much as the sea can. Don't compare a woman's love for a man with my love for Olivia.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
Ay, but I know -
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
Yes, but I know -

paragraphs.original:
ORSINO
What dost thou know?
paragraphs.translated:
ORSINO
What do you know?

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
Too well what love women to men may owe.
In faith, they are as true of heart as we.
My father had a daughter loved a man
As it might be, perhaps, were I a woman,
I should your lordship.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
I know a lot about the love women can feel for men. Actually, their hearts are as sensitive and loyal as ours are. My father had a daughter who loved a man in the same way that I might love you, if I were a woman.

paragraphs.original:
ORSINO
And what's her history?
paragraphs.translated:
ORSINO
And what's her story?

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
A blank, my lord. She never told her love,
But let concealment, like a worm i' the bud,
Feed on her damask cheek. She pined in thought,
And with a green and yellow melancholy
She sat like patience on a monument,
Smiling at grief. Was not this love indeed?
We men may say more, swear more, but indeed
Our shows are more than will, for still we prove
Much in our vows, but little in our love.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
There was no story, my lord. She never told him she loved him. She kept her love bottled up inside her until it destroyed her, ruining her beauty. She pined away. She just sat waiting patiently, sadly, smiling despite her sadness. Her complexion turned greenish from depression. Doesn't that sound like true love? We men might talk more and promise more, but in fact we talk more than we really feel. We might be great at making vows, but our love isn't sincere.

paragraphs.original:
ORSINO
But died thy sister of her love, my boy?
paragraphs.translated:
ORSINO
But did your sister die of love?

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
I am all the daughters of my father's house,
And all the brothers too - and yet I know not.
Sir, shall I to this lady?
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
I am the only daughter in my father's family, and all the brothers too - but I'm not completely sure about that. Anyway, sir, should I go see the lady?

paragraphs.original:
ORSINO
Ay, that's the theme.
To her in haste. Give her this jewel. Say
My love can give no place, bide no denay.
(he hands her a jewel)
(he hands her a jewel)
paragraphs.translated:
ORSINO
Yes, go quickly and give her this jewel. Tell her my love won't go away and won't be denied. (he hands her a jewel)
(he hands her a jewel)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original:
Enter SIR TOBY BELCH, SIR ANDREW, and FABIAN
SIR TOBY BELCH
SIR ANDREW
FABIAN
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH, SIR ANDREW, and FABIAN enter.
SIR TOBY BELCH
SIR ANDREW
FABIAN

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Come thy ways, Signior Fabian.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Come along with us, Signor Fabian.

paragraphs.original:
FABIAN
Nay, I'll come. If I lose a scruple of this sport, let me be boiled to death with melancholy.
paragraphs.translated:
FABIAN
I'm coming, don't worry. If I miss this, let me be boiled alive.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Wouldst thou not be glad to have the niggardly rascally sheep-biter come by some notable shame?
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Won't you be glad to see that rascal dog humiliated?

paragraphs.original:
FABIAN
I would exult, man. You know, he brought me out o' favor with my lady about a bear-baiting here.
paragraphs.translated:
FABIAN
I'll be thrilled. You know, he got me in trouble with the lady of the house once when I arranged a bear-baiting here.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
To anger him, we'll have the bear again, and we will fool him black and blue. Shall we not, Sir Andrew?
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
We'll have another bear-baiting just to make him angry, and we'll mock him till he's black and blue. Won't we, Sir Andrew?

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
An we do not, it is pity of our lives.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
If we don't, it'll be the biggest disappointment of our lives.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Here comes the little villain.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Here comes the little villain herself.

paragraphs.original:
Enter MARIA
MARIA
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA enters.
MARIA

paragraphs.original: How now, my metal of India?
paragraphs.translated: How are you, my golden girl?

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
Get you all three into the boxtree. Malvolio's coming down this walk. He has been yonder i' the sun practising behavior to his own shadow this half hour. Observe him, for the love of mockery, for I know this letter will make a contemplative idiot of him. Close, in the name of jesting!
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
Hide behind the boxwood hedge, all three of you. Malvolio's coming down the path. He's been over there practicing how to act for the past half hour. Watch him carefully if you want to have some fun, guys. This letter's going to turn him into a starry-eyed idiot. Now hide, for God's sake!

paragraphs.original: They hide
paragraphs.translated: They all hide.

paragraphs.original: Lie thou there (throwing down a letter), for here comes the trout that must be caught with tickling.
paragraphs.translated:
Now, you lie there on the path. (MARIA throws down a letter) Here comes the fish that's going to gobble up our bait.
(
throws down a letter)

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA exits.
MARIA

paragraphs.original:
Enter MALVOLIO
MALVOLIO
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO enters.
MALVOLIO

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
'Tis but fortune, all is fortune. Maria once told me she did affect me, and I have heard herself come thus near, that, should she fancy, it should be one of my complexion. Besides, she uses me with a more exalted respect than anyone else that follows her. What should I think on 't?
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
It's all luck. Everything's luck. Maria once told me Olivia was fond of me. I've almost heard Olivia say that herself. She said if she were interested in someone, it would be someone who looked like me. Besides, she treats me more respectfully than the other servants. What's the obvious conclusion from that?

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(aside) Here's an overweening rogue!
aside
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(whispering) What an egomaniac!
(whispering)

paragraphs.original:
FABIAN
(aside) O, peace! Contemplation makes a rare turkey-cock of him. How he jets under his advanced plumes!
(aside)
paragraphs.translated:
FABIAN
(whispering) Shh! When he's alone with his thoughts, he's even more like a haughty peacock. Watch him strut!
(whispering)

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
(aside) 'Slight, I could so beat the rogue!
aside
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
(whispering) I swear, I'd like to beat the jerk so hard!
(whispering)

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(aside) Peace, I say.
aside
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(whispering) Be quiet!
(whispering)

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
To be Count Malvolio!
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
Just think, I could be Count Malvolio!

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(aside) Ah, rogue!
aside
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(whispering) Ah, what a jerk!
(whispering)

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
(aside) Pistol him, pistol him.
aside
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
(whispering) Shoot him, just shoot him.
(whispering)

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(aside) Peace, peace!
aside
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(whispering) Shh, shh!
(whispering)

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
There is example for 't. The lady of the Strachy married the yeoman of the wardrobe.
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
After all, it wouldn't be the first time that kind of thing has happened. Lady Strachy married her wardrobe manager.

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
(aside) Fie on him, Jezebel!
aside
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
(whispering) Damn him, the arrogant fool!
(whispering)

paragraphs.original:
FABIAN
(aside) O, peace! Now he's deeply in. Look how imagination blows him.
(aside)
paragraphs.translated:
FABIAN
(whispering) Shh! We've got him right where we want him. He's on a big ego trip.
(whispering)

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
Having been three months married to her, sitting in my state -
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
Just think of me, having been married to her for three months, sitting around majestically -

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(aside) Oh, for a stone-bow, to hit him in the eye!
aside
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(whispering) If only I had a slingshot so I could hit him in the eye!
(whispering)

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
Calling my officers about me, in my branched velvet gown, having come from a daybed, where I have left Olivia sleeping -
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
Calling my servants together, wearing an embroidered robe, having just come from a couch where I've left Olivia sleeping -

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(aside) Fire and brimstone!
aside
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(whispering) That does it!
(whispering)

paragraphs.original:
FABIAN
(aside) O, peace, peace!
aside
paragraphs.translated:
FABIAN
(whispering) Oh, be quiet, be quiet!
(whispering)

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
And then to have the humor of state, and after a demure travel of regard, telling them I know my place as I would they should do theirs, to ask for my kinsman Toby -
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
Then I'd put on a lofty and exalted expression. I'd look around the room calmly, then tell them that I know my place, and I'd like them to know theirs. Then I'd tell them to go find my cousin Toby -

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(aside) Bolts and shackles!
aside
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(whispering) That really does it!
(whispering)

paragraphs.original:
FABIAN
(aside) O peace, peace, peace! Now, now.
aside
paragraphs.translated:
FABIAN
(whispering) Oh, quiet, quiet! Please, please.
(whispering)

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
Seven of my people, with an obedient start, make out for him. I frown the while, and perchance wind up watch, or play with my - some rich jewel. Toby approaches, curtsies there to me -
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
I'd send seven of my servants to go get him. While I waited, I'd frown impatiently, and perhaps wind my watch, or play with my - with some expensive piece of jewelry I happen to be wearing. Toby would approach me. He'd bow to me -

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(aside) Shall this fellow live?
aside
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(whispering) Are we going to let this guy live?
(whispering)

paragraphs.original:
FABIAN
(aside) Though our silence be drawn from us with cars, yet peace.
(aside)
paragraphs.translated:
FABIAN
(whispering) Yes, we have to be quiet, even if it's torture.
(whispering)

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
I extend my hand to him thus, quenching my familiar smile with an austere regard of control -
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
I reach out my hand to him like this, giving him a stern look instead of my usual friendly smile -

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(aside) And does not Toby take you a blow o' the lips then?
aside
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(whispering) And then doesn't Toby punch you in the mouth?
(whispering)

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
Saying, "Cousin Toby, my fortunes having cast me on your niece give me this prerogative of speech - "
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
And I'd say to him, "Cousin Toby, since I've been lucky enough to marry your niece, I have the right to say a few things to you - "

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(aside) What, what?
aside
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(whispering) Oh yeah, like what?
(whispering)

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
"You must amend your drunkenness."
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
"You must stop being such a drunk."

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(aside) Out, scab!
aside
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(whispering) Get out of here, you scab!
(whispering)

paragraphs.original:
FABIAN
(aside) Nay, patience, or we break the sinews of our plot.
aside
paragraphs.translated:
FABIAN
(whispering) No, be quiet, or we'll screw up the joke.
(whispering)

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
"Besides, you waste the treasure of your time with a foolish knight - "
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
"And you're wasting your time with that foolish knight - "

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
(aside) That's me, I warrant you.
aside
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
(whispering) That's me, I bet.
(whispering)

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
"One Sir Andrew - "
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
"That Sir Andrew - "

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
(aside) I knew 'twas I, for many do call me fool.
aside
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
(whispering) I knew he was talking about me. A lot of people call me foolish.
(whispering)

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
(seeing the letter) What employment have we here?
seeing the letter
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
(seeing the letter) What's this?
seeing the letter

paragraphs.original:
FABIAN
(aside) Now is the woodcock near the gin.
aside
paragraphs.translated:
FABIAN
(whispering) He's taking the bait.
(whispering)

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(aside) O, peace! And the spirit of humors intimate reading aloud to him!
(aside)
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(whispering) Shhh! I hope he reads it out loud, to make it funnier!
(whispering)

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
(picking up the letter) By my life, this is my lady's hand these be her very C's, her U's and her T's and thus makes she her great P's. It is, in contempt of question, her hand.
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
(picking up the letter) My goodness, this is my lady's
handwriting! These are her C's, her U's and her T's, and that's how she makes her big P's. It's definitely her handwriting, no doubt about it.
picking up the letter
handwriting

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
(aside) Her C's, her U's and her T's. Why that?
aside
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
(whispering) Her C's, her U's, and her T's. Why focus on that?
(whispering)

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
(reads) "To the unknown beloved, this, and my good wishes" - Her very phrases! By your leave, wax. Soft! And the impressure her Lucrece, with which she uses to seal. 'Tis my lady. To whom should this be?
(reads)
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
(reads) To my dear beloved who doesn't know I love him, I send you this letter with all my heart" - That's exactly how she talks! Excuse me, sealing wax. (he breaks the seal) Wait! This is the stamp my lady seals her letters with - it has a picture of Lucrece on it. This letter is from Olivia. Who is this written to?
(reads)
(he breaks the seal)

paragraphs.original:
FABIAN
(aside) This wins him, liver and all.
aside
paragraphs.translated:
FABIAN
(whispering) This'll get him.
(whispering)

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
(reads)
(reads)
"Jove knows I love,
But who?
Lips, do not move;
No man must know."
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
(he reads)
(he reads)
God knows I love someone.
But who?
I can't let my lips say his name;
"No man must know."

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
"No man must know." What follows? The numbers altered. "No man must know." If this should be thee, Malvolio?
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
"No man must know." What comes after that? Look, the meter changes in her poem. "No man must know." What if this someone were you, Malvolio?

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(aside) Marry, hang thee, brock!
aside
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(whispering) Go hang yourself, you stinking badger!
(whispering)

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
(reads)
(reads)
"I may command where I adore,
But silence, like a Lucrece knife,
With bloodless stroke my heart doth gore;
M.O.A.I. doth sway my life."
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
(reading)
(reading)
"I may order the one I love.
But silence, like a knife, cuts open my heart
With strokes that draw no blood.
M.O.A.I. rules my life."

paragraphs.original:
FABIAN
(aside) A fustian riddle!
aside
paragraphs.translated:
FABIAN
(whispering) What a pretentious riddle!
(whispering)

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(aside) Excellent wench, say I.
aside
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(whispering) That Maria has outdone herself!
(whispering)

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
"M.O.A.I. doth sway my life." Nay, but first, let me see, let me see, let me see.
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
"M.O.A.I. rules my life." Hmm, let me see, let me see, let me see.

paragraphs.original:
FABIAN
(aside) What dish o' poison has she dressed him!
aside
paragraphs.translated:
FABIAN
(whispering) What a dish of poison she's mixed for him!
(whispering)

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(aside) And with what wing the staniel checks at it!
aside
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(whispering) And look how willingly he's taking the bait.
(whispering)

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
"I may command where I adore." Why, she may command me. I serve her, she is my lady. Why, this is evident to any formal capacity. There is no obstruction in this. And the end - what should that alphabetical position portend? If I could make that resemble something in me - Softly! M.O.A.I. -
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
"I may command the one I love." Well, she commands me. I'm her servant. She's my boss. Why, anyone can see what this means. There's no ambiguity here. But the end, what do those letters mean? If only I could somehow relate them to me! Hmm. M.O.A.I. -

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(aside) O, ay, make up that. - He is now at a cold scent.
aside
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(whispering) Oh, bad dog. - He's losing the scent!
(whispering)

paragraphs.original:
FABIAN
(aside) Sowter will cry upon 't for all this, though it be as rank as a fox.
(aside)
paragraphs.translated:
FABIAN
(whispering) He'll find it again, no matter how much it stinks.
(whispering)

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
"M" - Malvolio. "M" - why, that begins my name.
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
"M" - Malvolio. "M" - why, that's the first letter in my name.

paragraphs.original:
FABIAN
(aside) Did not I say he would work it out? The cur is excellent at faults.
(aside)
paragraphs.translated:
FABIAN
(whispering) Didn't I tell you he'd figure it out? This dog's excellent at following false leads.
(whispering)

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
"M." But then there is no consonancy in the sequel that suffers under probation "A" should follow but "O" does.
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
"M." But then the next letter isn't the same. "A" should be next, but instead "O" comes next.

paragraphs.original:
FABIAN
(aside) And "O" shall end, I hope.
aside
paragraphs.translated:
FABIAN
(whispering) And an "O" like a noose will end this, I hope.
(whispering)

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(aside) Ay, or I'll cudgel him and make him cry "O!"
aside
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(whispering)Yeah, or I'll beat him up and make him yell "Oh!"
(whispering)

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
And then "I" comes behind.
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
And then the "I" comes next.

paragraphs.original:
FABIAN
(aside) Ay, an you had any eye behind you, you might see more detraction at your heels than fortunes before you.
(aside)
paragraphs.translated:
FABIAN
(whispering) If you had an I in the back of your head, you'd see trouble behind you.
(whispering)

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
"M.O.A.I." This simulation is not as the former, and yet to crush this a little, it would bow to me, for every one of these letters are in my name. Soft, here follows prose.
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
M.O.A.I. This code's not as easy to crack as the other one. But if I shake it up a little it'll work, because every one of those letters is in my name. But wait, there's some prose after her poem.

paragraphs.original:
(reads)
(reads)
"If this fall into thy hand, revolve. In my stars I am above thee, but be not afraid of greatness. Some are born great, some achieve greatness, and some have greatness thrust upon 'em. Thy Fates open their hands. Let thy blood and spirit embrace them. And, to inure thyself to what thou art like to be, cast thy humble slough and appear fresh. Be opposite with a kinsman, surly with servants.
paragraphs.translated:
(he reads)
(he reads)
"If this letter falls into your hands, think carefully about what it says. By my birth I rank above you, but don't be afraid of my greatness. Some are born great, some achieve greatness, and some have greatness thrust upon them. Your fate awaits you. Accept it in body and spirit. To get used to the life you'll most likely be leading soon, get rid of your low-class trappings. Show some eagerness for the new upscale lifestyle that's waiting

paragraphs.original:
Let thy tongue tang arguments of state. Put thyself into the trick of singularity. She thus advises thee that sighs for thee. Remember who commended thy yellow stockings and wished to see thee ever cross-gartered. I say, remember. Go to, thou art made, if thou desir'st to be so; if not, let me see thee a steward still, the fellow of servants, and not worthy to touch Fortune's fingers. Farewell. She that would alter services with thee,
The Fortunate Unhappy"
paragraphs.translated:
for you. Argue with a relative like a nobleman, and be rude to servants. Talk about politics and affairs of state, and act free and independent. The woman who advises you to do this loves you. Remember the woman who complimented you on your yellow stockings, and said she always wanted to see you with crisscrossing laces going up your legs - remember her. Go ahead. A happy new life is there if you want it. If you don't want it, just keep acting like a lowly servant who's not brave enough to grab the happiness there before him. Goodbye. Signed, she who would be your servant,
The Fortunate Unhappy."

paragraphs.original: Daylight and champaign discovers not more. This is open. I will be proud, I will read politic authors, I will baffle Sir Toby, I will wash off gross acquaintance, I will be point- devise the very man. I do not now fool myself, to let imagination jade me, for every reason excites to this, that my lady loves me. She did commend my yellow stockings of late, she did praise my leg being cross-gartered, and in this she manifests herself to my love, and with a kind of injunction, drives me to these habits of her liking. I thank my stars I am happy. I will be strange, stout, in yellow stockings, and cross-gartered, even with the swiftness of putting on. Jove and my stars be praised! Here is yet a postscript.
paragraphs.translated: This is as clear as sunlight in an open field. I'll do it. I'll be vain and proud, I'll read up on politics, I'll insult Sir Toby, I'll get rid of my lower-class friends, and I'll be the perfect man for her. I know I'm not fooling myself, or letting myself get carried away by my imagination, because every clue points to the fact that Lady Olivia loves me. She did compliment me on my yellow stockings recently, and she said she liked how the crisscross laces looked on my legs. That's her way of saying she loves me. Oh, I thank my lucky stars, I'm so happy. For her I'll be strange and condescending, and I'll put on my yellow stockings and crisscross laces right away. Thank God and my horoscope! Here's a postscript!.

paragraphs.original:
(reads)
(reads)
"Thou canst not choose but know who I am. If thou entertainest my love, let it appear in thy smiling. Thy smiles become thee well. Therefore in my presence still smile, dear my sweet, I prithee."
paragraphs.translated:
(reads)
(reads)
"You must have figured out who I am. If you love me, let me know by smiling at me. You're so attractive when you smile. Please smile whenever you're near me, my dearest darling."

paragraphs.original: Jove, I thank thee! I will smile. I will do everything that thou wilt have me.
paragraphs.translated: Dear God, thank you! I'll do everything she wants me to do.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO exits.
MALVOLIO

paragraphs.original:
FABIAN
I will not give my part of this sport for a pension of thousands to be paid from the Sophy.
paragraphs.translated:
FABIAN
I wouldn't have missed this even for a pension of thousands of pounds, to be paid by the shah of Persia.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
I could marry this wench for this device.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
I could marry that Maria for thinking this up.

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
So could I too.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
So could I.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
And ask no other dowry with her but such another jest.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
And I wouldn't ask for any dowry except for her to play another trick like this one.

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
Nor I neither.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
Neither would I.

paragraphs.original:
Enter MARIA
MARIA
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA enters.
MARIA

paragraphs.original:
FABIAN
Here comes my noble gull-catcher.
paragraphs.translated:
FABIAN
Here she comes, the brilliant fool-catcher.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Wilt thou set thy foot o' my neck?
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
May I kiss your feet?

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
Or o' mine either?
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
And I too?

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Shall I play my freedom at tray-trip, and become thy bondslave?
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Shall I be your slave?

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
I' faith, or I either?
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
Me too.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Why, thou hast put him in such a dream that when the image of it leaves him he must run mad.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
You've made him so delusional he'll go crazy when he learns the truth.

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
Nay, but say true, does it work upon him?
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
Did it really work?

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Like aqua vitae with a midwife.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Like medicine for a sick man.

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
If you will then see the fruits of the sport, mark his first approach before my lady. He will come to her in yellow stockings, and 'tis a color she abhors, and cross-gartered, a fashion she detests. And he will smile upon her, which will now be so unsuitable to her disposition, being addicted to a melancholy as she is, that it cannot but turn him into a notable contempt. If you will see it, follow me.
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
If you want to really have some fun, watch him next time he's near Lady Olivia. He'll show up in yellow stockings - she hates yellow - and with laces crisscrossing up his legs - she hates that style of dress - and he'll smile, which will go completely against her mood, since she's addicted to sadness now. She'll definitely get upset with him. If you want to watch, follow me.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
To the gates of Tartar, thou most excellent devil of wit!
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
I'd follow you to the gates of Hell, you sneaky little devil!

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
I'll make one too.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
I'll come too.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original:
Enter VIOLA, and the FOOL playing with a tabor
VIOLA
FOOL
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA and the FOOL, playing a drum, enter.
VIOLA
FOOL

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
Save thee, friend, and thy music. Dost thou live by thy tabour?
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
God bless you, my friend, and your music too. Do you make your living by playing that drum?

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
No, sir, I live by the church.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
No, sir, I live by the church.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
Art thou a churchman?
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
Oh, you're a clergyman?

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
No such matter, sir. I do live by the church; for I do live at my house, and my house doth stand by the church.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
No, I live by the church because I live in a house, and my house is by the church.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
So thou mayst say the king lies by a beggar if a beggar dwell near him, or the church stands by thy tabor, if thy tabor stand by the church.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
You could just as easily say that a king sleeps near a beggar if the beggar lives near him, or that the church is supported by your drum because it "stands by" your drum.

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
You have said, sir. To see this age! A sentence is but a cheveril glove to a good wit. How quickly the wrong side may be turned outward!
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
You're right, sir. What a wonderful time to be alive! Sentences can be turned inside out so easily nowadays!

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
Nay, that's certain. They that dally nicely with words may quickly make them wanton.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
That's true. People who fool around with words too much can make words act like whores - changing all the time, and immoral too.

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
I would therefore my sister had no name, sir.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
That's why I wish my sister didn't have a name, sir.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
Why, man?
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
Why, man?

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
Why, sir, her name's a word, and to dally with that word might make my sister wanton. But, indeed, words are very rascals since bonds disgraced them.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
Well, her name's a word, and if you fooled around with it you might make her into a whore. But, you know, words have been rascals ever since people started using written contracts rather than their word of honor.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
Thy reason, man?
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
Why do you say that?

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
Troth, sir, I can yield you none without words, and words are grown so false, I am loath to prove reason with them.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
Honestly, sir, I'd need to use words to explain why, and since words are so unreliable and false, I'd rather avoid using them in a serious discussion.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
I warrant thou art a merry fellow and carest for nothing.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
I bet you're a happy fellow who doesn't care about anything.

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
Not so, sir, I do care for something. But in my conscience, sir, I do not care for you. If that be to care for nothing, sir, I would it would make you invisible.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
You're wrong, sir, I do care about something. But I'll admit I don't care for you. If that means I don't care about anything, you should disappear right now, since you're nothing.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
Art not thou the Lady Olivia's fool?
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
Aren't you Lady Olivia's fool?

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
No, indeed, sir; the Lady Olivia has no folly. She will keep no fool, sir, till she be married, and fools are as like husbands as pilchards are to herrings; the husband's the bigger: I am indeed not her fool, but her corrupter of words.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
No, sir. Lady Olivia doesn't want to have anything to do with foolishness. So she won't have a fool until she gets married. Fools are to husbands as anchovies are to sardines - husbands are the bigger ones. I'm not her fool. I just make words into whores for her.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
I saw thee late at the Count Orsino's.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
I saw you at Count Orsino's recently.

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
Foolery, sir, does walk about the orb like the sun. It shines everywhere. I would be sorry, sir, but the fool should be as oft with your master as with my mistress: I think I saw your wisdom there.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
I'm everywhere. Foolishness is all over the world, just like sunshine. I'd be sorry if people thought your master was less familiar with foolishness than my mistress is. I think I saw you there, you wise man.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
Nay, an thou pass upon me, I'll no more with thee. Hold, there's expenses for thee.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
Oh no, if you're joking around with me, I'm leaving. Wait, here's a coin for you.

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
Now Jove, in his next commodity of hair, send thee a beard!
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
Next time God sends out a shipment of hair, I hope he gives you a beard!

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
By my troth, I'll tell thee, I am almost sick for one, (aside) though I would not have it grow on my chin. (to fool) Is thy lady within?
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
Oh, I know. Seriously, I'm dying for one, (to herself) I mean, I'm dying for a man who has a beard; I don't want one to grow on my chin. (to the FOOL) Is Lady Olivia inside?
(to herself)
(to the

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
Would not a pair of these have bred, sir?
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
If I had two of these coins, do you think they'd breed more coins?

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
Yes, being kept together and put to use.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
Yes, if you kept them together and invested them.

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
I would play Lord Pandarus of Phrygia, sir, to bring a
Cressida to this Troilus.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
I'd like to be like that famous pimp, Lord Pandarus, and get a
Cressida for my Troilus.
Cressida for my Troilus

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
(giving him money) I understand you, sir. 'Tis well begged.
(giving him money)
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
(giving the FOOL money) I get what you're driving at, sir. You're a very clever beggar.
(giving the
money)

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
The matter, I hope, is not great, sir, begging but a beggar. Cressida was a beggar. My lady is within, sir. I will construe to them whence you come. Who you are and what you would are out of my welkin, I might say "element," but the word is overworn.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
It shouldn't be too much to ask; I'm only begging for a beggar. They say Cressida became a beggar in her old age. My lady Olivia's inside, sir. I'll tell them where you come from, though I don't know who you are or what you want. I'd say I was "out of my element," but that phrase is overused, so I'll say I'm "out of my air."

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated:
The FOOL exits.
FOOL

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
This fellow is wise enough to play the fool,
And to do that well craves a kind of wit.
He must observe their mood on whom he jests,
The quality of persons, and the time,
And, like the haggard, check at every feather
That comes before his eye. This is a practise
As full of labor as a wise man's art,
For folly that he wisely shows is fit.
But wise men, folly-fall'n, quite taint their wit.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
This guy's wise enough to play the fool, and only clever people can do that. He pays attention to the mood and social rank of the person he's joking with, and also to the time of day. And he doesn't let go of his target when a distraction appears. His job requires as much effort and skill as any wise man's occupation could. And he shows he's very smart at playing the fool, while smart people look stupid when they play the fool.

paragraphs.original:
Enter SIR TOBY BELCH, and SIR ANDREW
SIR TOBY BELCH
SIR ANDREW
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH and SIR ANDREW enter.
SIR TOBY BELCH
SIR ANDREW

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Save you, gentleman.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Hello, sir.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
And you, sir.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
Hello to you too, sir.

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
Dieu vous garde, monsieur.
Dieu vous garde, monsieur.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
(speaking in French) May God protect you, sir.
(speaking in French)

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
Et vous aussi. Votre serviteur!
Et vous aussi. Votre serviteur!
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
(speaking in French) And you too, sir. I'm at your service.
(speaking in French)

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
I hope, sir, you are, and I am yours.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
(
stammering) Oh, good, I am too.
stammering

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Will you encounter the house? My niece is desirous you should enter, if your trade be to her.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
My niece would like you to come in to the house, if your business here has to do with her.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
I am bound to your niece, sir. I mean, she is the list of my voyage.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
I'm headed for your niece, sir. She's the reason I'm here.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Taste your legs, sir. Put them to motion.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Taste your legs, sir. Please go inside.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
My legs do better understand me, sir, than I understand what you mean by bidding me taste my legs.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
Taste my legs? My legs stand under me, but I don't understand what "taste your legs" means.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
I mean, to go, sir, to enter.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
I mean please go into the house, sir.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
I will answer you with gait and entrance. But we are prevented.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
I will. But now we don't have to!

paragraphs.original:
Enter OLIVIA and MARIA
OLIVIA
MARIA
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA and MARIA enter.
OLIVIA
MARIA

paragraphs.original: Most excellent accomplished lady, the heavens rain odors on you!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, beautiful and accomplished lady, may the heavens rain odors upon you!

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
(aside) That youth's a rare courtier. "Rain odors." Well.
aside
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
(to himself) That young man's classy. "Rain odors." That's good.
(to himself)

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
My matter hath no voice, lady, but to your own most pregnant and vouchsafed ear.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
My message is not for anyone else to hear, my lady. It's only for your willing and receptive ear.

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
(aside) "Odors," "pregnant," and "vouchsafed." I'll get
(aside)
'em all three all ready.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
(to himself) "Odors," "willing," and "deserving." I'll have to remember those words so I can use them later myself.
(to himself) "

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Let the garden door be shut, and leave me to my hearing.
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Close the garden door and leave me alone to hear his message.

paragraphs.original:
Exeunt SIR TOBY BELCH, SIR ANDREW, and MARIA
SIR TOBY BELCH
SIR ANDREW
MARIA
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH, SIR ANDREW, and MARIA exit.
SIR TOBY BELCH
SIR ANDREW
MARIA

paragraphs.original: Give me your hand, sir.
paragraphs.translated: Give me your hand, sir.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
My duty, madam, and most humble service.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
I give you my obedience and my humble service, madam.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
What is your name?
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
What's your name?

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
Cesario is your servant's name, fair princess.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
Cesario is my name - your servant's name - fair princess.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
My servant, sir! 'Twas never merry world
Since lowly feigning was call'd compliment.
You're servant to the Count Orsino, youth.
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
My servant! The world's gone downhill since fake humility started passing for compliments. You're not my servant, young man. You're Count Orsino's servant.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
And he is yours, and his must needs be yours:
Your servant's servant is your servant, madam.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
But he's your servant, so everything that's his must be yours too. Your servant's servant is your servant, madam.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
For him, I think not on him. For his thoughts,
Would they were blanks, rather than fill'd with me.
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
As for him, I never think about him. As for his thoughts, I wish he'd think about nothing at all rather than think about me all the time.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
Madam, I come to whet your gentle thoughts
On his behalf.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
Madam, I've come here to try to make you like him.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
O, by your leave, I pray you,
I bade you never speak again of him.
But, would you undertake another suit,
I had rather hear you to solicit that
Than music from the spheres.
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Oh, please, I'm begging you, don't mention him again. But if you want to tell me that someone else loves me, I'd enjoy hearing that more than I'd enjoy listening to angels sing.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
Dear lady -
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
My dear lady -

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Give me leave, beseech you. I did send,
After the last enchantment you did here,
A ring in chase of you. So did I abuse
Myself, my servant, and, I fear me, you:
Under your hard construction must I sit,
To force that on you, in a shameful cunning
Which you knew none of yours. What might you think?
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Please let me say something, I'm begging you. After you cast your magic spell on me last time, I sent you a ring. I fear it was a mistake, since I tricked my servant, myself, and you too. You probably think poorly of me after I forced that ring on you with such outrageous trickery. What else could you possibly think of me?

paragraphs.original:
Have you not set mine honor at the stake,
And baited it with all the unmuzzled thoughts
That tyrannous heart can think? To one of your receiving
Enough is shown. A cypress, not a bosom,
Hides my heart. So, let me hear you speak.
paragraphs.translated: Haven't you totally dismissed my honor and integrity in your anger? For someone as intelligent as you the situation must be clear enough. I'm wearing my heart on my sleeve, and I can't hide my feelings. So let me hear what you have to say.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
I pity you.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
I feel sorry for you.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
That's a degree to love.
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
That's a step in the direction of love.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
No, not a grize. For 'tis a vulgar proof
That very oft we pity enemies.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
No, not at all. It's a perfectly ordinary experience for us to feel sorry for our enemies.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Why then methinks 'tis time to smile again.
O world, how apt the poor are to be proud!
If one should be a prey, how much the better
To fall before the lion than the wolf! (clock strikes)
clock strikes
The clock upbraids me with the waste of time.
Be not afraid, good youth, I will not have you.
And yet when wit and youth is come to harvest,
Your wife is like to reap a proper man.
There lies your way, due west.
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Well, enough of my whining then. That's that! I was getting carried away with fantasies I didn't deserve to have. But I should consider myself lucky. It's much better to be destroyed by a noble enemy than by a cruel and heartless one. (a clock strikes) Listen to that, the clock's scolding me for wasting my time loving you. Don't worry, young man, I won't stalk you. And when you're older and wiser and ready for marriage, your future wife will have a fine husband. There's the way back home for you, due west.
(a clock strikes)

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
Then westward ho!
Grace and good disposition attend your ladyship!
You'll nothing, madam, to my lord by me?
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
Then west is where I'm headed! I wish you all the best. You do

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Stay, I prithee, tell me what thou thinkest of me.
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Stay, Please, tell me what you think of me.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
That you do think you are not what you are.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
I think you're denying what you really are.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
If I think so, I think the same of you.
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
If that's true, I think the same thing about you.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
Then think you right: I am not what I am.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
You're right. I am not what I am.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
I would you were as I would have you be!
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
I wish you were what I wanted you to be!

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
Would it be better, madam, than I am?
I wish it might, for now I am your fool.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
Would it be better if I were that, instead of what I am? I wish I were something better, because right now I'm a big fool.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
(aside) Oh, what a deal of scorn looks beautiful
(aside)
In the contempt and anger of his lip!
A murderous guilt shows not itself more soon
Than love that would seem hid. Love's night is noon.
(to VIOLA) Cesario, by the roses of the spring,
(to
By maidhood, honor, truth, and everything,
I love thee so, that, maugre all thy pride,
Nor wit nor reason can my passion hide.
Do not extort thy reasons from this clause,
For that I woo, thou therefore hast no cause,
But rather reason thus with reason fetter.
Love sought is good, but given unsought better.
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
(to herself) Oh, how beautiful he is even when he's angry and full of contempt! A murderer can hide his guilt longer than someone in love can hide her love. Love shines brightly and can't be hidden. (to VIOLA) Cesario, I swear by the spring roses, by virginity, honor, truth, and everything, I swear I love you. I love you so much that I can't hide my passion for you, as clever as I am. Don't assume that because I'm pursuing you there's no reason to pursue me. Put two and two together and realize that asking for love is good, but getting it without asking is much better.
(to herself)
(to

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
By innocence I swear, and by my youth
I have one heart, one bosom, and one truth,
And that no woman has, nor never none
Shall mistress be of it, save I alone.
And so adieu, good madam. Nevermore
Will I my master's tears to you deplore.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
And I swear by my youth and innocence that I've only got one heart and one love to give, and that I've never given them to a woman and never will. So goodbye, my lady. I won't ever come to complain about my lord's love for you again.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Yet come again, for thou perhaps mayst move
That heart, which now abhors, to like his love.
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Then come again for another reason. You might still be able to make yourself fall in love with me, the person he loves, even though you hate me now.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original:
Enter SIR TOBY BELCH, SIR ANDREW, and FABIAN
SIR TOBY BELCH
SIR ANDREW
FABIAN
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH, SIR ANDREW, and FABIAN enter.
SIR TOBY BELCH
SIR ANDREW
FABIAN

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
No, faith, I'll not stay a jot longer.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
No, I won't stay a second longer.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Thy reason, dear venom, give thy reason.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Why are you leaving, my angry friend?

paragraphs.original:
FABIAN
