You must needs yield your reason, Sir Andrew.
paragraphs.translated:
FABIAN
Yes, you have to tell us why, Sir Andrew.

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
Marry, I saw your niece do more favors to the Count's servingman than ever she bestowed upon me. I saw 't i' the orchard.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
Well, because I saw your niece Olivia treat the count's messenger better than she's ever treated me. I saw it in the orchard.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Did she see thee the while, old boy? Tell me that.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Did she see you there the whole time, old boy? Tell me that.

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
As plain as I see you now.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
Yes, she saw me quite clearly.

paragraphs.original:
FABIAN
This was a great argument of love in her toward you.
paragraphs.translated:
FABIAN
Well, that proves she's in love with you.

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
'Slight, will you make an ass o' me?
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
Are you trying to make fun of me?

paragraphs.original:
FABIAN
I will prove it legitimate, sir, upon the oaths of judgment and reason.
paragraphs.translated:
FABIAN
No, I'll prove it with airtight evidence and logical argument.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
And they have been grand-jurymen since before Noah was a sailor.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
And you can't deny evidence and argument - They've been around since Noah's ark.

paragraphs.original:
FABIAN
She did show favor to the youth in your sight only to exasperate you, to awake your dormouse valor, to put fire in your heart and brimstone in your liver. You should then have accosted her, and with some excellent jests, fire-new from the mint, you should have banged the youth into dumbness.
paragraphs.translated:
FABIAN
She flirted with the messenger boy to exasperate you, fire up your passions, and make you angry and jealous. You should have run up to her, unleashed a few excellent quips invented on the spot, and rendered the young man speechless.

paragraphs.original: This was looked for at your hand, and this was balked. The double gilt of this opportunity you let time wash off, and you are now sailed into the north of my lady's opinion, where you will hang like an icicle on a Dutchman's beard, unless you do redeem it by some laudable attempt either of valor or policy.
paragraphs.translated: That's what she was expecting, and you let her down. You wasted a golden opportunity, and now my lady thinks badly of you. You can only raise her opinion of you with some impressive act of courage or complicated intrigue.

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
An 't be any way, it must be with valor, for policy I hate. I had as lief be a Brownist as a politician.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
I'll have to do something courageous then, because I hate intrigue. I'd rather be a heretic than a schemer with fancy plots.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Why, then, build me thy fortunes upon the basis of valor. Challenge me the count's youth to fight with him. Hurt him in eleven places. My niece shall take note of it, and assure thyself, there is no love-broker in the world can more prevail in man's commendation with woman than report of valor.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Well then, improve your situation with a show of courage. Challenge the count's young servant to a fight. Hurt him in eleven different places. My niece Olivia will notice, and let me tell you, no matchmaker in the world can get you a woman faster than a reputation for courage.

paragraphs.original:
FABIAN
There is no way but this, Sir Andrew.
paragraphs.translated:
FABIAN
It's really the only way, Sir Andrew.

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
Will either of you bear me a challenge to him?
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
Will either of you give him the message that I'm challenging him to a duel?

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Go, write it in a martial hand. Be curst and brief. It is no matter how witty, so it be eloquent and full of invention. Taunt him with the license of ink. If thou "thou"-est him some thrice, it shall not be amiss; and as many lies as will lie in thy sheet of paper, although the sheet were big enough for the bed of Ware in England, set 'em down. Go, about it. Let there be gall enough in thy ink, though thou write with a goose-pen, no matter. About it.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Go ahead and write it down. Make your handwriting look like a soldier's. Be pointed and brief. It doesn't need to be witty as long as it's eloquent and imaginative. Taunt him as much as you want, since you're only doing it in writing. It's fine if you refer to him as "thou" instead of
"you." Write down as many lies as you can fit on a sheet of paper. Go ahead, get on with it. You may be using an ordinary pen, but you can fill it with poison ink. Now get busy.
"you."

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
Where shall I find you?
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
Where will I find you when I've finished it?

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
We'll call thee at the cubiculo. Go.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
We'll come find you in the bedroom. Go on.

paragraphs.original:
Exit SIR ANDREW
SIR ANDREW
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW exits.
SIR ANDREW

paragraphs.original:
FABIAN
This is a dear manikin to you, Sir Toby.
paragraphs.translated:
FABIAN
This precious little guy is putty in your hands, Sir Toby.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
I have been dear to him, lad, some two thousand strong, or so.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
He must like me, since he's let me spend two thousand of his ducats.

paragraphs.original:
FABIAN
We shall have a rare letter from him: but you'll not deliver 't?
paragraphs.translated:
FABIAN
His letter's going to be hilarious. But you're not going to deliver it, are you?

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Never trust me, then. And by all means stir on the youth to an answer. I think oxen and wainropes cannot hale them together. For Andrew, if he were opened and you find so much blood in his liver as will clog the foot of a flea, I'll eat the rest of the anatomy.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Never trust me again if I don't. And by all means see if you can get the young man to answer it. I don't think a team of oxen could get them close enough to fight. If you dissected Andrew and found enough red blood in his
liver for a flea to eat, then I'd eat the rest of his corpse. He's a coward.
liver

paragraphs.original:
FABIAN
And his opposite, the youth, bears in his visage no great presage of cruelty.
paragraphs.translated:
FABIAN
And his opponent, the young messenger, doesn't look like he'd be very aggressive in a fight.

paragraphs.original:
Enter MARIA
MARIA
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA enters.
MARIA

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Look where the youngest wren of nine comes.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Here comes my little bird.

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
If you desire the spleen, and will laugh yourself into stitches, follow me. Yond gull Malvolio is turned heathen, a very renegado. For there is no Christian that means to be saved by believing rightly can ever believe such impossible passages of grossness. He's in yellow stockings.
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
Listen, if you want a good laugh - and I mean a side-splitting one - then follow me. That gullible idiot Malvolio must have renounced Christianity, since no Christian could do such outrageous things as he's doing. He's wearing yellow stockings.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
And cross-gartered?
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
With crisscrossed laces?

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
Most villanously, like a pedant that keeps a school i' the church. I have dogged him, like his murderer. He does obey every point of the letter that I dropped to betray him. He does smile his face into more lines than is in the new map with the augmentation of the Indies. You have not seen such a thing as 'tis. I can hardly forbear hurling things at him. I know my lady will strike him. If she do, he'll smile and take 't for a great favor.
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
Oh, he looks like a pathetic Sunday school teacher. I've stalked him like a murderer, and he's done everything the letter told him to. He smiles so much his face has more lines in it than a map of the East Indies. You've never seen anything like it. I can hardly keep myself from throwing things at him. I know that my lady's going to end up hitting him. And when she does, he'll imagine she's flirting with him.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Come, bring us, bring us where he is.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Come on, take us to him.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original:
Enter SEBASTIAN and ANTONIO
SEBASTIAN
ANTONIO
paragraphs.translated:
SEBASTIAN and ANTONIO enter.
SEBASTIAN
ANTONIO

paragraphs.original:
SEBASTIAN
I would not by my will have troubled you,
But, since you make your pleasure of your pains,
I will no further chide you.
paragraphs.translated:
SEBASTIAN
I really didn't want to inconvenience you. But since you seem to enjoy helping me, I won't nag you to stop any more.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONIO
I could not stay behind you. My desire,
More sharp than filèd steel, did spur me forth.
And not all love to see you, though so much
As might have drawn one to a longer voyage,
But jealousy what might befall your travel,
Being skilless in these parts, which to a stranger,
Unguided and unfriended, often prove
Rough and unhospitable. My willing love,
The rather by these arguments of fear,
Set forth in your pursuit.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONIO
I couldn't stay behind after you left. I just felt a sharp desire to follow you. It wasn't just that I wanted to see you, though I very much did want that. I was also worried about what might happen to you while you were traveling, since you're not familiar with this area, and it's rough and unwelcoming to a stranger with no guide. I followed you because I love you and I was worried about you.

paragraphs.original:
SEBASTIAN
My kind Antonio,
I can no other answer make but thanks,
And thanks, and ever thanks. And oft good turns
Are shuffled off with such uncurrent pay.
But were my worth as is my conscience, firm,
You should find better dealing. What's to do?
Shall we go see the relics of this town?
paragraphs.translated:
SEBASTIAN
My friend Antonio, all I can say is thank you. I know words are cheap. If I had any money I'd back up my gratitude with cash. Anyway, what should we do? Should we go see the sights in the town?

paragraphs.original:
ANTONIO
Tomorrow, sir. Best first go see your lodging.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONIO
We can do that tomorrow, sir. First we should make sure you have somewhere to stay.

paragraphs.original:
SEBASTIAN
I am not weary, and 'tis long to night:
I pray you, let us satisfy our eyes
With the memorials and the things of fame
That do renown this city.
paragraphs.translated:
SEBASTIAN
I'm not tired, and night is a long time away. Come on, let's go see the sights.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONIO
Would you'd pardon me;
I do not without danger walk these streets:
Once in a sea-fight 'gainst the Count his galleys
I did some service, of such note indeed,
That were I ta'en here it would scarce be answered.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONIO
I'm sorry, but I can't. You see, it's dangerous for me to walk in these streets. Once in a battle at sea I did a lot of damage to Count Orsino's warships. If they arrested me here, it'd be the end of me.

paragraphs.original:
SEBASTIAN
Belike you slew great number of his people?
paragraphs.translated:
SEBASTIAN
You probably killed a lot of his men?

paragraphs.original:
ANTONIO
The offence is not of such a bloody nature;
Albeit the quality of the time and quarrel
Might well have given us bloody argument.
It might have since been answered in repaying
What we took from them, which, for traffic's sake,
Most of our city did. Only myself stood out;
For which, if I be lapsèd in this place,
I shall pay dear.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONIO
No, I didn't do anything as violent as that, though we would've been justified in shedding a little blood over the matter. The whole quarrel might have been resolved since then when we repaid what we stole from them - which most of our city did, for the sake of friendly trade relations. I was the only one who refused to give back what I stole. That's why I'll pay dearly if they find me here.

paragraphs.original:
SEBASTIAN
Do not then walk too open.
paragraphs.translated:
SEBASTIAN
Then don't make yourself too conspicuous.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONIO
It doth not fit me. Hold, sir, here's my purse.
(giving him money)
(giving him money)
In the south suburbs, at the Elephant,
Is best to lodge. I will bespeak our diet,
Whiles you beguile the time and feed your knowledge
With viewing of the town. There shall you have me.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONIO
You're right. Hang on a minute, here's some money for you. (he gives SEBASTIAN money) The best place to stay around here is an inn called the Elephant, in the suburbs south of the city. I'll arrange for our meals while you enjoy yourself and educate yourself by looking at the town. You'll find me at the Elephant.
(he gives
money)

paragraphs.original:
SEBASTIAN
Why I your purse?
paragraphs.translated:
SEBASTIAN
Why are you giving me your purse?

paragraphs.original:
ANTONIO
Haply your eye shall light upon some toy
You have desire to purchase, and your store,
I think, is not for idle markets, sir.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONIO
Maybe you'll see some little trinket you want to buy. I doubt you've got enough money for little purchases like that.

paragraphs.original:
SEBASTIAN
I'll be your purse-bearer and leave you
For an hour.
paragraphs.translated:
SEBASTIAN
I'll hold on to your money and leave you for an hour.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONIO
To the Elephant.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONIO
We'll meet at the Elephant.

paragraphs.original:
SEBASTIAN
I do remember.
paragraphs.translated:
SEBASTIAN
I remember.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original:
Enter OLIVIA and MARIA
OLIVIA
MARIA
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA and MARIA enter.
OLIVIA
MARIA

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
I have sent after him. He says he'll come.
How shall I feast him? What bestow of him?
For youth is bought more oft than begged or borrow'd.
I speak too loud. - 
Where's Malvolio? He is sad and civil
And suits well for a servant with my fortunes.
Where is Malvolio?
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
I've sent for him. He says he'll come. What kind of food should I serve him? What presents should I give him? It's easier to buy young people than to beg or borrow them. Oh, I'm talking too loud. - Where's Malvolio? He's very serious, which is right for someone in mourning like me. Where is Malvolio?

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
He's coming, madam; but in very strange manner. He is sure possessed, madam.
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
He's coming, madam; but he's acting very strangely. He must be possessed by the devil.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Why, what's the matter? Does he rave?
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Why, what's the matter with him? Is he talking nonsense?

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
No, madam, he does nothing but smile. Your ladyship were best to have some guard about you if he come, for sure the man is tainted in 's wits.
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
No, he just smiles. You should have a guard nearby if he comes in here, because he's clearly disturbed.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Go call him hither.
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Ask him in here.

paragraphs.original:
Exit MARIA
MARIA
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA exits.
MARIA

paragraphs.original:
I am as mad as he,
If sad and merry madness equal be.
paragraphs.translated: I'm as crazy as he is, if sad craziness and happy craziness are equivalent.

paragraphs.original:
Enter MARIA, with MALVOLIO
MARIA
MALVOLIO
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA enters with MALVOLIO.
MARIA
MALVOLIO

paragraphs.original: How now, Malvolio?
paragraphs.translated: What's going on, Malvolio?

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
Sweet lady, ho, ho.
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
Hello, sweet lady.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Smilest thou? I sent for thee upon a sad occasion.
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
You're smiling? I sent for you about a sad occasion.

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
Sad, lady! I could be sad. This does make some obstruction in the blood, this cross-gartering, but what of that? If it please the eye of one, it is with me as the very true sonnet is, "Please one, and please all."
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
Sad, my lady! I could be sad if I wanted to be. These crisscrossing laces do cut off the circulation in my legs a bit, but who cares? As the sonnet says, "If you please one special person, you please everyone who matters."

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Why, how dost thou, man? What is the matter with thee?
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Why, what's going on? What's the matter with you?

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
Not black in my mind, though yellow in my legs. It did come to his hands, and commands shall be executed. I think we do know the sweet Roman hand.
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
My legs may be yellow, but I don't feel blue. It was addressed to him, and orders must be obeyed. I think we know whose fancy handwriting that was.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Wilt thou go to bed, Malvolio?
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Don't you think you should go to bed, Malvolio?

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
To bed? "Ay, sweetheart, and I'll come to thee."
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
To bed! "Yes, sweetheart, I'll come to you."

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
God comfort thee! Why dost thou smile so, and kiss thy hand so oft?
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
For heaven's sake, why are you smiling like that and kissing your hand so much?

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
How do you, Malvolio?
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
How are you feeling, Malvolio?

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
At your request! Yes, nightingales answer daws!
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
You're asking me! Noble people don't answer to peasants!

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
Why appear you with this ridiculous boldness before my lady?
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
Why are you acting so brazen toward my lady?

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
"Be not afraid of greatness." 'Twas well writ.
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
"Don't be afraid of greatness." That was well written.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
What meanest thou by that, Malvolio?
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
What do you mean by that, Malvolio?

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
"Some are born great - "
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
"Some are born great - "

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Ha?
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
What?

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
"Some achieve greatness - "
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
"Some achieve greatness - "

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
What sayest thou?
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
What are you saying?

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
"And some have greatness thrust upon them."
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
"And some have greatness thrust upon them."

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Heaven restore thee!
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Heaven help you!

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
"Remember who commended thy yellow stockings - "
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
"Remember who liked your yellow stockings - "

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Thy yellow stockings?
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Your yellow stockings?

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
"And wished to see thee cross-gartered."
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
"And wanted to see you with laces crisscrossed over your legs."

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Cross-gartered?
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Crisscrossed?

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
"Go to, thou art made, if thou desirest to be so - "
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
"Go ahead. A happy new life is there if you want it - "

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Am I made?
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Am I a new life?

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
"If not, let me see thee a servant still."
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
"If you don't want it, just keep acting like a lowly servant."

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Why, this is very midsummer madness.
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
This is completely insane.

paragraphs.original:
Enter SERVANT
SERVANT
paragraphs.translated:
SERVANT enters.
SERVANT

paragraphs.original:
SERVANT
Madam, the young gentleman of the Count Orsino's is returned. I could hardly entreat him back. He attends your ladyship's pleasure.
paragraphs.translated:
SERVANT
Madam, Count Orsino's young messenger has returned. It was hard to get him to come back, but he's here now, waiting for you.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
I'll come to him.
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
I'll go to him.

paragraphs.original:
Exit SERVANT
SERVANT
paragraphs.translated:
SERVANT exits.
SERVANT

paragraphs.original: Good Maria, let this fellow be looked to. Where's my cousin Toby? Let some of my people have a special care of him. I would not have him miscarry for the half of my dowry.
paragraphs.translated: Maria, take care of this poor fellow here. Where's my cousin Toby? Have some of my servants take care of Malvolio. I'd give half my dowry to keep anything bad from happening to him.

paragraphs.original:
Exeunt OLIVIA and MARIA
OLIVIA
MARIA
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA and MARIA exit.
OLIVIA
MARIA

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
Oh, ho! Do you come near me now? No worse man than Sir Toby to look to me. This concurs directly with the letter. She sends him on purpose that I may appear stubborn to him, for she incites me to that in the letter. "Cast thy humble slough," says she. "Be opposite with a kinsman, surly with servants. Let thy tongue tang with arguments of state. Put thyself into the trick of singularity," and consequently sets down the manner how: as, a sad face, a reverend carriage, a slow tongue, in the habit of some sir of note, and so forth. I have limed her, but it is Jove's doing, and Jove make me thankful! And when she went away now, "Let this fellow be looked to." "Fellow!" Not "Malvolio," nor after my degree, but "fellow." Why, everything adheres together, that no dram of a scruple, no scruple of a scruple, no obstacle, no incredulous or unsafe circumstance - what can be said? Nothing that can be can come between me and the full prospect of my hopes. Well, Jove, not I, is the doer of this, and he is to be thanked.
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
Oh ho! Look at me now! No less a person than Sir Toby, Lady Olivia's own relative, is going to take care of me. This is just what the letter said. She's sending him to me on purpose, so I can be rude to him just like she said in the letter. "Get rid of your low-class trapping," she said. "Argue with a relative of mine like a nobleman, and be rude to servants. Talk about politics and affairs of state, and act free and independent." And then she explains how to do it: I should have a serious face and dignified demeanor, well-modulated speech, acting like a distinguished gentleman and so on. I've got her now, but I've got God to thank for it! And when she left just now, she said "Take care of this poor fellow here." Fellow!" Not "Malvolio," not anything referring to my low station in life, but "fellow." Everything's going perfectly. Not the tiniest ounce, not the littlest insignificant amount of trouble or bad luck could ruin it - what can I say? Nothing can come between me and the fulfillment of all my hopes. Well, God is responsible for that, not me, and he deserves thanks.

paragraphs.original:
Enter MARIA, with SIR TOBY BELCH and FABIAN
MARIA
SIR TOBY BELCH
FABIAN
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA enters with SIR TOBY BELCH and FABIAN.
MARIA
SIR TOBY BELCH
FABIAN

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Which way is he, in the name of sanctity? If all the devils of hell be drawn in little, and Legion himself possessed him, yet I'll speak to him.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Where is he, for God's sake? I don't care if all the devils in hell crammed together to possess him, I still want to speak to him.

paragraphs.original:
FABIAN
Here he is, here he is. How is't with you, sir? How is't with you, man?
paragraphs.translated:
FABIAN
Here he is, here he is. How are you, sir?

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
Go off, I discard you. Let me enjoy my private. Go off.
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
Go away. I don't want to see your face. Let me enjoy my privacy. Go away.

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
(to SIR TOBY BELCH) Lo, how hollow the fiend speaks within him! Did not I tell you? Sir Toby, my lady prays you to have a care of him.
(to
)
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
(to SIR TOBY BELCH) Ooh, listen to the scary devil speaking from inside him! Didn't I tell you? Sir Toby, Lady Olivia wants you to take care of him.
(to
)

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
Aha! Does she so?
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
Ah-ha! Does she?

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(to FABIAN and MARIA) Go to, go to! Peace, peace. We must deal gently with him. Let me alone. - How do you, Malvolio? How is 't with you? What, man, defy the devil! Consider, he's an enemy to mankind.
(to
and
)
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(to FABIAN and MARIA) Come on, come on! Calm down, calm down. We need to treat him gently. Let me take care of this. - How are you, Malvolio? How are things? Come on, man, just say no to the devil! Think about it, he's the enemy of mankind.
(to
and
)

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
Do you know what you say?
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
Do you even know what you're talking about?

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
(to SIR TOBY BELCH) La you, an you speak ill of the devil, how he takes it at heart! Pray God, he be not bewitched!
(to
)
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
(to SIR TOBY BELCH) Look at that, he acts insulted if you say bad things about the devil! I hope to God he's not bewitched!
(to
)

paragraphs.original:
FABIAN
Carry his water to the wisewoman.
paragraphs.translated:
FABIAN
Get a urine sample and take it to a witch doctor to find out.

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
Marry, and it shall be done tomorrow morning if I live. My lady would not lose him for more than I'll say.
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
Sure thing, we'll do it tomorrow morning. My lady would never want to lose him.

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
How now, mistress?
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
What are you saying, mistress?

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
O Lord!
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
Oh, Lord!

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(to MARIA) Prithee, hold thy peace. This is not the way. Do you not see you move him? Let me alone with him.
(to
)
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(to MARIA) Please, keep quiet. This is not the way to act. Don't you see you're upsetting him? Leave me alone with him.
(to
)

paragraphs.original:
FABIAN
No way but gentleness, gently, gently. The fiend is rough and will not be roughly used.
paragraphs.translated:
FABIAN
Gentleness is the only way to go - gently, gently. The devil inside him is rough, but we can't treat it roughly.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(to MALVOLIO) Why, how now, my bawcock! How dost thou, chuck?
(to
)
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(to the imaginary devil inside MALVOLIO) So how are you, my pretty little bird? How are you doing in there, sweet little chicken?
(to the imaginary devil inside
)

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
Sir!
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
Sir!

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Ay, Biddy, come with me. - What, man! 'Tis not for gravity to play at cherry-pit with Satan. Hang him, foul collier!
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Yes, dear little chick, come along with me. - Shut up, man! You're serious enough to know not to play games with Satan. Damn that dirty black coalminer of a devil!

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
Get him to say his prayers, good Sir Toby, get him to pray.
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
Get him to say his prayers, Sir Toby, get him to pray.

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
My prayers, minx?
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
My prayers, you hussy?

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
(to SIR TOBY BELCH) No, I warrant you, he will not hear of godliness.
(to
)
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
(to SIR TOBY BELCH) No, I'm telling you, he refuses to hear anything about religion.
(to
)

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
Go, hang yourselves all! You are idle, shallow things. I am not of your element. You shall know more hereafter.
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
Go hang yourselves, all of you! You're all lazy and shallow. I'm not like you. I have a higher future waiting for me. You'll know more about it later.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO exits.
MALVOLIO

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Is 't possible?
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Is it possible?

paragraphs.original:
FABIAN
If this were played upon a stage now, I could condemn it as an improbable fiction.
paragraphs.translated:
FABIAN
If this were a play, I'd complain it was unrealistic.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
His very genius hath taken the infection of the device, man.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
He's really taken this prank to heart. He's playing the role perfectly.

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
Nay, pursue him now, lest the device take air and taint.
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
No, follow him now, before he divulges the prank and ruins everything.

paragraphs.original:
FABIAN
Why, we shall make him mad indeed.
paragraphs.translated:
FABIAN
Wow, we're really going to drive him crazy.

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
The house will be the quieter.
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
The house will be so much quieter.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Come, we'll have him in a dark room and bound. My niece is already in the belief that he's mad. We may carry it thus, for our pleasure and his penance, till our very pastime, tired out of breath, prompt us to have mercy on him, at which time we will bring the device to the bar and crown thee for a finder of madmen. But see, but see!
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Come on, let's put him in a dark room and tie him up. My niece already thinks he's insane. We can go on like this, punishing him and having some fun, until we're tired of it. Then we can take mercy on him and let him out, and talk about how well the joke went. We'll also worship you for setting up this trick. Let's do it, let's do it!

paragraphs.original:
Enter SIR ANDREW
SIR ANDREW
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW enters.
SIR ANDREW

paragraphs.original:
FABIAN
More matter for a May morning.
paragraphs.translated:
FABIAN
Here's more insanity for us.

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
(presenting a paper) Here's the challenge, read it. Warrant there's vinegar and pepper in 't.
(presenting a paper)
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
(presenting them a piece of paper) Here's the challenge, read it. It's bursting with fighting words.
(presenting them a piece of paper)

paragraphs.original:
FABIAN
Is 't so saucy?
paragraphs.translated:
FABIAN
Is it that aggressive?

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
Ay, is 't, I warrant him. Do but read.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
Yes, it is, I think. Just read it.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Give me. (reads) "Youth, whatsoever thou art, thou art but a scurvy fellow."
(reads)
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Give it to me. (he reads) "Young man, whatever you are, you're a real scum bucket."
(he reads)

paragraphs.original:
FABIAN
Good, and valiant.
paragraphs.translated:
FABIAN
Nice. Very courageous.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(reads) "Wonder not, nor admire not in thy mind, why I do call thee so, for I will show thee no reason for 't."
(reads)
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(reading) "Don't even ask why I call you that, because I won't give you any explanation."
(reading)

paragraphs.original:
FABIAN
A good note, that keeps you from the blow of the law.
paragraphs.translated:
FABIAN
That's a good thing to put in - it keeps you from getting in trouble with the law.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(reads) "Thou comest to the lady Olivia, and in my sight she uses thee kindly. But thou liest in thy throat. That is not the matter I challenge thee for."
(reads)
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(reading) "You come to see the lady Olivia, and she's kind to you. But you're a complete liar. That's not why I'm challenging you to a duel."
(reading)

paragraphs.original:
FABIAN
Very brief, and to exceeding good sense - less.
paragraphs.translated:
FABIAN
Nice and short and full of good sense - or should I say nonsense?

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(reads) "I will waylay thee going home, where if it be thy chance to kill me - "
(reads)
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(reading) "I'll ambush you on your way home, and if you're lucky enough to kill me - "
(reading)

paragraphs.original:
FABIAN
Good.
paragraphs.translated:
FABIAN
Good.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(reads) "Thou killest me like a rogue and a villain."
(reads)
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(reading) "You'll be killing me like a common criminal, a mugger."
(reading)

paragraphs.original:
FABIAN
Still you keep o' the windy side of the law. Good.
paragraphs.translated:
FABIAN
You still haven't said anything incriminating. Good.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(reads) "Fare thee well, and God have mercy upon one of our souls. He may have mercy upon mine, but my hope is better, and so look to thyself. Thy friend, as thou usest him, and thy sworn enemy,
(reads)
Andrew Aguecheek"
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(reading) "Good luck, and may God have mercy on one of our souls. He may have mercy upon mine. But I have a better chance of surviving, so watch out. Signed, your friend, if you treat him right, and your sworn enemy,
(reading)
Andrew Aguecheek"

paragraphs.original: If this letter move him not, his legs cannot. I'll give 't him.
paragraphs.translated: If this letter doesn't make him fight, I don't know what will. I'll give it to him.

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
You may have very fit occasion for 't. He is now in some commerce with my lady and will by and by depart.
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
You might have a great opportunity to give it to him right now. He's conducting some business with my lady, and sooner or later he'll leave.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Go, Sir Andrew. Scout me for him at the corner the orchard like a bum-baily. So soon as ever thou seest him, draw, and as thou drawest, swear horrible, for it comes to pass oft that a terrible oath, with a swaggering accent sharply twanged off, gives manhood more approbation than ever proof itself would have earned him. Away!
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Go, Sir Andrew. Look out for him in the corner of the orchard as if you were a sheriff's deputy. As soon as you see him, draw your sword, and as you draw it, start swearing horribly. Sometimes a terrible swear word, like a well-shot arrow, makes you look more brave and manly than getting in a fight would. Now go!

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
Nay, let me alone for swearing.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
Don't worry about me not swearing enough.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW exits.
SIR ANDREW

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Now will not I deliver his letter, for the behavior of the young gentleman gives him out to be of good capacity and breeding. His employment between his lord and my niece confirms no less. Therefore this letter, being so excellently ignorant, will breed no terror in the youth. He will find it comes from a clodpole. But, sir, I will deliver his challenge by word of mouth, set upon Aguecheek a notable report of valor, and drive the gentleman (as I know his youth will aptly receive it) into a most hideous opinion of his rage, skill, fury, and impetuosity. This will so fright them both that they will kill one another by the look, like cockatrices.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
I won't deliver this letter. The young gentleman's behavior shows that he's sensible and has good manners. The fact that he serves as a go-between for his lord and my niece Olivia confirms this. So this letter, which is so incredibly stupid and ignorant, isn't going to scare him at all. He'll just think an idiot wrote it. But I'll deliver Sir Andrew's challenge by word of mouth, describing Sir Andrew as courageous in battle and convincing the young gentleman that Sir Andrew is furious, impetuous, and a skilled fighter (he'll believe me because he's young). This will make them both so afraid that they'll kill each other just by looking at each other.

paragraphs.original:
Enter OLIVIA, with VIOLA
OLIVIA
VIOLA
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA enters with VIOLA.
OLIVIA
VIOLA

paragraphs.original:
FABIAN
Here he comes with your niece. Give them way till he take leave, and presently after him.
paragraphs.translated:
FABIAN
Here comes the messenger with your niece. Leave them alone until he sets off home, and then follow him.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
I will meditate the while upon some horrid message for a challenge.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Meanwhile, I'll think of some horrible way to phrase the challenge.

paragraphs.original:
Exeunt SIR TOBY BELCH, FABIAN, and MARIA
Exeunt SIR TOBY BELCH
FABIAN
MARIA
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH, FABIAN, and MARIA exit.
SIR TOBY BELCH
FABIAN
MARIA

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
I have said too much unto a heart of stone
And laid mine honor too unchary on 't.
There's something in me that reproves my fault,
But such a headstrong potent fault it is
That it but mocks reproof.
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
I've said too much to someone with a heart of stone. I've foolishly jeopardized my honor and reputation. I hate myself for behaving that way, but I just had to, and no criticism could have stopped me.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
With the same 'havior that your passion bears
Goes on my master's grief.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
My lord acts just as crazy with love as you do.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Here, wear this jewel for me. 'Tis my picture.
Refuse it not. It hath no tongue to vex you.
And I beseech you come again tomorrow.
What shall you ask of me that I'll deny,
That honor, saved, may upon asking give?
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Here, take this piece of jewelry. There's a picture of me inside. Don't refuse it. It won't annoy you like me, because it doesn't have a voice. And I beg you, please come here again tomorrow. What could you possibly ask of me that I wouldn't give you, as long as it didn't damage my honor and self-respect?

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
Nothing but this: your true love for my master.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
Nothing, except your true love for my lord.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
How with mine honor may I give him that
Which I have given to you?
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
How could I honorably give him what I've already given you?

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
I will acquit you.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
I'll give it back to you.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Well, come again tomorrow. Fare thee well.
A fiend like thee might bear my soul to hell.
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Just come again tomorrow. Good-bye. A devil like you could lead me to hell.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA exits.
OLIVIA exits

paragraphs.original:
Enter SIR TOBY BELCH and FABIAN
SIR TOBY BELCH
FABIAN
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH and FABIAN enter.
SIR TOBY BELCH
FABIAN

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Gentleman, God save thee.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Hello, sir.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
And you, sir.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
Hello to you.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
That defense thou hast, betake thee to 't. Of what nature the wrongs are thou hast done him, I know not, but thy intercepter, full of despite, bloody as the hunter, attends thee at the orchard end. Dismount thy tuck, be yare in thy preparation, for thy assailant is quick, skillful and deadly.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
You'd better think up a way to defend yourself. I don't know what you've done to upset him, but someone has challenged you to a duel. He's riled up and bloodthirsty, and he's waiting for you at the back of the orchard. Draw your sword and get on your toes, because your assailant is quick, skillful, and deadly.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
You mistake, sir. I am sure no man hath any quarrel to me. My remembrance is very free and clear from any image of offense done to any man.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
There must be some mistake, sir. I'm sure nobody would have any reason to fight with me. I can't remember anything I've ever done to offend anyone.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
You'll find it otherwise, I assure you. Therefore, if you hold your life at any price, betake you to your guard, for your opposite hath in him what youth, strength, skill, and wrath can furnish man withal.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
You're wrong about that, I assure you. So if you value your life at all, be on your guard. Your opponent has enough youth, strength, skill, and anger to outfight anyone.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
I pray you, sir, what is he?
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
But who is this person, sir?

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
He is knight, dubbed with unhatched rapier and on carpet consideration, but he is a devil in private brawl. Souls and bodies hath he divorced three, and his incensement at this moment is so implacable that satisfaction can be none but by pangs of death and sepulchre. Hob, nob, is his word. "Give 't or take 't."
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
He's a knight. He was made a knight because of his court connections, but when he's fighting a civilian he's a real monster. He's killed three people, and he's so furious right now that the only thing that will satisfy him is seeing you die. "Fight to the death" is his motto.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
I will return again into the house and desire some conduct of the lady. I am no fighter. I have heard of some kind of men that put quarrels purposely on others, to taste their valor. Belike this is a man of that quirk.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
I'll go back inside and ask the lady for some kind of escort. I'm not a fighter. I've heard of men who pick fights with other people on purpose, just to see how brave they are. This man is probably like that.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Sir, no. His indignation derives itself out of a very competent injury. Therefore get you on and give him his desire. Back you shall not to the house, unless you undertake that with me which with as much safety you might answer him. Therefore on, or strip your sword stark naked, for meddle you must, that's certain, or forswear to wear iron about you.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
No, sir. He's furious because you insulted him, and he has a right to satisfaction. So go out there and give him what he wants. You can't go back into the house unless you want to fight with me - and if you're willing to do that, you might as well just go and fight with him. So go to the orchard, or take out your sword right now. You're going to have to fight one way or another, there's no doubt about that, or else you'll have to stop wearing a sword and claiming to be a gentleman.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
This is as uncivil as strange. I beseech you, do me this courteous office, as to know of the knight what my offense to him is. It is something of my negligence, nothing of my purpose.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
This is as rude as it is strange. Please, do me this one favor: find out what I've done to offend this knight. It must be something I did accidentally.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
I will do so. Signior Fabian, stay you by this gentleman till my return.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
I will do so. Mr. Fabian, stay with this gentleman until I come back.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY exits.
SIR TOBY

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
Pray you, sir, do you know of this matter?
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
Excuse me, sir, do you know anything about this?

paragraphs.original:
FABIAN
I know the knight is incensed against you, even to a mortal arbitrament, but nothing of the circumstance more.
paragraphs.translated:
FABIAN
I know the knight is furious with you, so much that he's willing to fight you to the death, but I don't know anything else about it.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
I beseech you, what manner of man is he?
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
What kind of man is he?

paragraphs.original:
FABIAN
Nothing of that wonderful promise, to read him by his form, as you are like to find him in the proof of his valor. He is, indeed, sir, the most skillful, bloody, and fatal opposite that you could possibly have found in any part of Illyria. Will you walk towards him? I will make your peace with him if I can.
paragraphs.translated:
FABIAN
He's not much to look at, but he's very brave in battle. He really is the most skillful, bloodthirsty, and dangerous opponent you can find in Illyria. Do you want to go see him? I'll try to calm him down for you if I can.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
I shall be much bound to you for 't. I am one that had rather go with sir priest than sir knight. I care not who knows so much of my mettle.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
I'd be very grateful to you if you did. I'm much more of a religious type than a fighter, and I don't care who knows it.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original:
Enter SIR TOBY BELCH, with SIR ANDREW
SIR TOBY BELCH
SIR ANDREW
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH enters with SIR ANDREW.
SIR TOBY BELCH
SIR ANDREW

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Why, man, he's a very devil. I have not seen such a firago. I had a pass with him, rapier, scabbard, and all, and he gives me the stuck-in with such a mortal motion, that it is inevitable. And on the answer, he pays you as surely as your feet hit the ground they step on. They say he has been fencer to the Sophy.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Wow, he's a real devil. I've never seen such a monster. I had a round with him, and his sword thrust is so deadly that you can't even duck out of the way. And when he strikes back at you, he'll hit you as sure as you're standing there. They say he used to fence for the shah of Persia.

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
Pox on 't! I'll not meddle with him.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
That's it! I won't mess with him.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Ay, but he will not now be pacified. Fabian can scarce hold him yonder.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Yes, but now there's no way to calm him down. Fabian can hardly control him over there.

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
Plague on 't, an I thought he had been valiant and so cunning in fence, I'd have seen him damned ere I'd have challenged him. Let him let the matter slip, and I'll give him my horse, gray Capilet.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
Darn it, if I'd guessed he was so brave and such a good swordsman, I never would have challenged him. I'll give him my gray horse Capilet if he forgets the whole thing.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
I'll make the motion. Stand here, make a good show on 't.
This shall end without the perdition of souls. (aside) Marry,
(aside)
I'll ride your horse as well as I ride you.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
I'll give it a try. Stay right here and try to look good. This may end without anyone getting killed. (to himself) I'll ride your horse just like I ride you.
(to himself)

paragraphs.original:
Enter FABIAN and VIOLA
FABIAN
VIOLA
paragraphs.translated:
FABIAN and VIOLA enter.
FABIAN
VIOLA

paragraphs.original:
FABIAN
He is as horribly conceited of him, and pants and looks pale, as if a bear were at his heels.
paragraphs.translated:
FABIAN
He's just as terrified of Sir Andrew. He's pale and hyperventilating, as if a bear were chasing him.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(to VIOLA) There's no remedy, sir; he will fight with you for 's oath sake. Marry, he hath better bethought him of his quarrel, and he finds that now scarce to be worth talking of. Therefore, draw for the supportance of his vow. He protests he will not hurt you.
(to
)
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(to VIOLA) There's nothing you can do about it, sir. He insists on fighting with you because he swore he would. But he's thought over his reason for challenging you to fight, and he realizes it's so insignificant that it's not worth thinking about. So draw your sword so he can carry out his vow. He promises not to hurt you.
(to
)

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
(aside) Pray God defend me! A little thing would make me tell them how much I lack of a man.
(aside)
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
(to herself) God help me! If anything happens I'm going to have to tell them exactly how unmanly I am.
(to herself)

paragraphs.original:
FABIAN
Give ground, if you see him furious.
paragraphs.translated:
FABIAN
Back off if he seems really furious.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Come, Sir Andrew, there's no remedy. The gentleman will, for his honor's sake, have one bout with you. He cannot by the duello avoid it. But he has promised me, as he is a gentleman and a soldier, he will not hurt you. Come on, to 't.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Come on, Sir Andrew, there's nothing you can do about it. The gentleman insists on fighting a round with you, for the sake of his honor. The rules of dueling say he has to. But as a gentleman and a soldier he's promised me he won't hurt you. Come on, get ready.

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
Pray God, he keep his oath!
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
I hope to God he keeps his promise!

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
I do assure you, 'tis against my will.
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
I swear to you, I don't want to be doing this.

paragraphs.original:
They draw swords Enter ANTONIO
ANTONIO
paragraphs.translated:
They draw their swords. ANTONIO enters.
ANTONIO

paragraphs.original:
ANTONIO
Put up your sword. If this young gentleman
Have done offence, I take the fault on me.
If you offend him, I for him defy you.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONIO
Put your sword away. If this young gentleman has offended you, I'll take the blame for it. If you've offended him, I'll fight you.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
You, sir? Why, what are you?
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
You, sir? Who are you?

paragraphs.original:
ANTONIO
One, sir, that for his love dares yet do more
Than you have heard him brag to you he will.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONIO
I'm just a good friend of his. In fact, I'd do even more to him than what you've heard him promise to do.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Nay, if you be an undertaker, I am for you.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
If you're someone who gets into fights, I'll fight with you.

paragraphs.original:
They draw swords Enter OFFICERS
OFFICERS
paragraphs.translated:
They draw their swords. OFFICERS enter.
OFFICERS

paragraphs.original:
FABIAN
O good Sir Toby, hold! Here come the officers.
paragraphs.translated:
FABIAN
Oh, Sir Toby, stop! The police are here.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(to ANTONIO) I'll be with you anon.
(to
)
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(to ANTONIO) I'll be back for you soon.
(to
)

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
(to ANDREW) Pray, sir, put your sword up, if you please.
(to
)
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
(to ANDREW) Please, sir, put away your sword. Please.
(to
)

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
Marry, will I, sir. And for that I promised you, I'll be as good as my word. He will bear you easily and reins well.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
I certainly will, sir. And as for what I promised to you, I'm as good as my word. You can ride him easily, and he responds well when you pull the reins.

paragraphs.original:
FIRST OFFICER
This is the man. Do thy office.
paragraphs.translated:
FIRST OFFICER
This is the man. Do your job.

paragraphs.original:
SECOND OFFICER
Antonio, I arrest thee at the suit of Count Orsino.
paragraphs.translated:
SECOND OFFICER
Antonio, you're under arrest on the orders of Count Orsino.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONIO
You do mistake me, sir.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONIO
You must be mistaking me for someone else, sir.

paragraphs.original:
FIRST OFFICER
No, sir, no jot. I know your favor well,
Though now you have no sea-cap on your head. - 
Take him away. He knows I know him well.
paragraphs.translated:
FIRST OFFICER
No, sir, not at all. I recognize your face perfectly, even without a sailor's cap on your head. - Take him away. He knows I recognize him.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONIO
I must obey. (to VIOLA) This comes with seeking you:
(to
)
But there's no remedy. I shall answer it.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONIO
I have to obey. (to VIOLA) This has happened because I came looking for you, but there's nothing I can do about it now. I'll take what's coming to me. But what'll you do now that I have to ask you for my purse back?
(to
)

paragraphs.original:
What will you do, now my necessity
Makes me to ask you for my purse? It grieves me
Much more for what I cannot do for you
Than what befalls myself. You stand amazed,
But be of comfort.
paragraphs.translated: I'm more upset about not being able to help you than I am about what's going to happen to me. You look so confused. Don't worry about me.

paragraphs.original:
SECOND OFFICER
Come, sir, away.
paragraphs.translated:
SECOND OFFICER
Come on, sir, let's go.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONIO
(to VIOLA) I must entreat of you some of that money.
(to
)
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONIO
(to VIOLA) Really, I must ask you for some of that money.
(to
)

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
What money, sir?
For the fair kindness you have showed me here,
And part being prompted by your present trouble,
Out of my lean and low ability
I'll lend you something. My having is not much.
I'll make division of my present with you.
Hold, there's half my coffer. (offering him money)
(offering him money)
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
What money, sir? I feel sorry for you in this situation, and I want to thank you for the kindness you've shown me here, so I'll lend you some of my money, though I don't have much. I'll give you half of everything I have right now. Take this. It's half of all my money. (she offers him money)
(she offers him money)

paragraphs.original:
ANTONIO
Will you deny me now?
Is 't possible that my deserts to you
Can lack persuasion? Do not tempt my misery,
Lest that it make me so unsound a man
As to upbraid you with those kindnesses
That I have done for you.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONIO
Are you really going to pretend you don't know me now? After everything I've done for you, you're refusing to help me? Don't make me more miserable than I am. I might do something really weak and unmanly, like listing the kind things I've done for you.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
I know of none,
Nor know I you by voice or any feature.
I hate ingratitude more in a man
Than lying, vainness, babbling, drunkenness,
Or any taint of vice whose strong corruption
Inhabits our frail blood -
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
I don't know any kind things you've done for me, and I don't recognize your voice or your face. I hate an ungrateful man more than I hate lying, vanity, babbling, drunkenness, or any other vice that we feeble human beings are susceptible to. -

paragraphs.original:
ANTONIO
O heavens themselves!
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONIO
Oh, my God!

paragraphs.original:
SECOND OFFICER
Come, sir, I pray you, go.
paragraphs.translated:
SECOND OFFICER
Come on, sir, please. Let's go.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONIO
Let me speak a little. This youth that you see here
I snatched one half out of the jaws of death,
Relieved him with such sanctity of love,
And to his image, which methought did promise
Most venerable worth, did I devotion.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONIO
No, I've got something to say. I saved this young man's life when he was half-dead, and nursed him back to health lovingly and tenderly. I devoted myself to him, since he looked noble and good.

paragraphs.original:
FIRST OFFICER
What's that to us? The time goes by. Away!
paragraphs.translated:
FIRST OFFICER
Why should we care? Time's passing. Let's go!

paragraphs.original:
ANTONIO
But oh, how vile an idol proves this god!
Thou hast, Sebastian, done good feature shame.
In nature there's no blemish but the mind.
None can be called deformed but the unkind.
Virtue is beauty, but the beauteous evil
Are empty trunks o'erflourished by the devil.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONIO
But oh, what a deceiver he turned out to be! You don't live up to your good looks, Sebastian. You look good but you're bad on the inside, where it counts, since the only real flaws in nature are in a person's mind and soul. Only really cruel people can be called deformed. Virtue is beauty, but someone beautiful and wicked is like an empty box decorated by the devil.

paragraphs.original:
FIRST OFFICER
The man grows mad. Away with him. Come, come, sir.
paragraphs.translated:
FIRST OFFICER
The man's going crazy. Take him away. Come on, sir. Come on.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONIO
Lead me on.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONIO
Take me.

paragraphs.original:
Exit with OFFICERS
OFFICERS
paragraphs.translated:
He exits with the OFFICERS.
OFFICERS

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
Methinks his words do from such passion fly,
That he believes himself. So do not I.
Prove true, imagination, oh, prove true,
That I, dear brother, be now ta'en for you!
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
He was so angry I feel he must really believe what he was saying. I don't believe it. Yet I wish I could. Oh, please be true, please let it be that this man has mistaken me for you, my dear brother!

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Come hither, knight. Come hither, Fabian. We'll whisper o'er a couplet or two of most sage saws.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Come here, Sir Andrew. You too, Fabian. We've got some words of wisdom to mull over.

paragraphs.original:
VIOLA
He named Sebastian. I my brother know
Yet living in my glass. Even such and so
In favor was my brother, and he went
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA
He called me Sebastian. I know my brother's still alive in a sense, since I see him whenever I look in the mirror. My brother looked like me, and he dressed the same way that I'm dressed now - in the same colors,

paragraphs.original:
Still in this fashion, color, ornament,
For him I imitate. Oh, if it prove,
Tempests are kind and salt waves fresh in love!
paragraphs.translated: with the same accessories. Oh, if it turns out to be true that he survived, then that storm was kind, and the ocean was full of love!

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated:
VIOLA exits.
VIOLA

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
A very dishonest paltry boy, and more a coward than a hare. His dishonesty appears in leaving his friend here in necessity and denying him. And for his cowardship, ask Fabian.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
He's a very dishonest, puny boy, and more cowardly than a rabbit. He abandoned his friend here in an emergency, and even pretended he didn't know him. That shows he's dishonest. As for his cowardliness, ask Fabian.

paragraphs.original:
FABIAN
A coward, a most devout coward, religious in it.
paragraphs.translated:
FABIAN
He's a coward, a total coward. He's religiously devoted to his cowardice.

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
'Slid, I'll after him again and beat him.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
By God, I'll go after him again and beat him up.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Do, cuff him soundly, but never draw thy sword.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Please do. Beat him up well, but don't draw your sword.

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
An I do not -
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
I swear I will -

paragraphs.original:
FABIAN
Come, let's see the event.
paragraphs.translated:
FABIAN
Come on, let's go see what happens.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
I dare lay any money 'twill be nothing yet.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
I'll bet anything you like that nothing will happen, once again.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original:
Enter SEBASTIAN and FOOL
SEBASTIAN
FOOL
paragraphs.translated:
SEBASTIAN and the FOOL enter.
SEBASTIAN
FOOL

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
Will you make me believe that I am not sent for you?
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
Are you trying to tell me that I wasn't sent to get you?

paragraphs.original:
SEBASTIAN
Go to, go to, thou art a foolish fellow. Let me be clear of thee.
paragraphs.translated:
SEBASTIAN
Oh, who cares, you're acting like a fool. Leave me alone.

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
Well held out, i' faith. No, I do not know you, nor I am not sent to you by my lady, to bid you come speak with her, nor your name is not Master Cesario, nor this is not my nose neither. Nothing that is so is so.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
Good for you, holding out on me like this! No, I don't know you, and my lady didn't send me to get you, and I'm not supposed to tell you to come speak with her, and your name is not Master Cesario, and this is not my nose, either. Nothing is what it is.

paragraphs.original:
SEBASTIAN
I prithee, vent thy folly somewhere else. Thou know'st not me.
paragraphs.translated:
SEBASTIAN
Oh please, go somewhere else to blab your nonsense. You don't know me.

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
Vent my folly? He has heard that word of some great man and now applies it to a fool. Vent my folly! I am afraid this great lubber, the world, will prove a cockney. I prithee now, ungird thy strangeness and tell me what I shall vent to my lady. Shall I vent to her that thou art coming?
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
Blab my nonsense? He must've heard that phrase describing some great man and now he's using it on a jester. Blab my nonsense! What an idiotic place this world is. Now please stop being so strange and tell me what exactly I should blab to my lady. Should I blab to her that you're coming?

paragraphs.original:
SEBASTIAN
I prithee, foolish Greek, depart from me. There's money for thee. (giving money) If you tarry longer, I shall give worse payment.
(giving money)
paragraphs.translated:
SEBASTIAN
Please, fool, go away. Here's money for you. (giving him money) If you stay any longer, I'll give you something worse.
(giving him money)

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
By my troth, thou hast an open hand. These wise men that give fools money get themselves a good report - after fourteen years' purchase.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
Well, well. You're a generous man. Wise men who give fools money might get a good reputation - if they keep up regular payments for fourteen years.

paragraphs.original:
Enter SIR ANDREW, SIR TOBY BELCH, and FABIAN
SIR ANDREW
SIR TOBY BELCH
FABIAN
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW, SIR TOBY BELCH, and FABIAN enter.
SIR ANDREW
SIR TOBY BELCH
FABIAN

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
(to SEBASTIAN) Now, sir, have I met you again? There's for you.
(to
)
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
Well, sir, we meet again? Take that.

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW strikes SEBASTIAN
SIR ANDREW
SEBASTIAN
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW hits SEBASTIAN.
SIR ANDREW
SEBASTIAN

paragraphs.original:
SEBASTIAN
(returning the blow) Why, there's for thee, and there, and there. Are all the people mad?
(returning the blow)
paragraphs.translated:
SEBASTIAN
(returning the blow) Well, then, take that, and that, and that. Is everyone here insane?
(returning the blow)

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Hold, sir, or I'll throw your dagger o'er the house.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Stop right now or I'll throw your dagger over the roof.

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
(aside) This will I tell my lady straight. I would not be in some of your coats for two pence.
(aside)
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
(to himself) I'm going to tell my lady about this right away. I wouldn't be in any of your shoes if you paid me.
(to himself)

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL exits.
FOOL

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(seizing SEBASTIAN) Come on, sir, hold!
seizing
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(grabbing SEBASTIAN) Come on, sir, stop!
(grabbing
)

paragraphs.original:
SIR ANDREW
Nay, let him alone. I'll go another way to work with him. I'll have an action of battery against him if there be any law in Illyria. Though I struck him first, yet it's no matter for that.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR ANDREW
No, leave him alone. I'll get back at him another way. I'll sue him for assault and battery, if there's any justice in Illyria. It doesn't matter that I hit him first.

paragraphs.original:
SEBASTIAN
(to SIR TOBY BELCH) Let go thy hand.
(to
)
paragraphs.translated:
SEBASTIAN
(to SIR TOBY BELCH) Let me go.
(to
)

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Come, sir, I will not let you go. Come, my young soldier, put up your iron. You are well fleshed. Come on.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
No, sir, I won't let you go. Come on, put your sword away, my little soldier. You're awfully eager to fight. Come on.

paragraphs.original:
SEBASTIAN
I will be free from thee.
paragraphs.translated:
SEBASTIAN
I'll get free of you.

paragraphs.original:
SEBASTIAN pulls free and draws his sword
SEBASTIAN
paragraphs.translated:
SEBASTIAN pulls free and draws his sword.
SEBASTIAN

paragraphs.original: What wouldst thou now? If thou darest tempt me further, draw thy sword.
paragraphs.translated: What are you going to do now? If you insist on trying my patience any further, then take out your sword right now.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
What, what? Nay, then I must have an ounce or two of this malapert blood from you.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
What? No. Because then I'd have to shed an ounce or two of your impudent blood.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH draws his sword Enter OLIVIA
SIR TOBY BELCH
OLIVIA
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH draws his sword. OLIVIA enters.
SIR TOBY BELCH
OLIVIA

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Hold, Toby! On thy life I charge thee, hold!
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Stop, Sir Toby! I order you to stop!

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Madam!
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Madam!

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Will it be ever thus? Ungracious wretch,
Fit for the mountains and the barbarous caves,
Where manners ne'er were preach'd! Out of my sight! - 
Be not offended, dear Cesario. - 
Rudesby, be gone!
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Are you always going to be like this? You're an ungrateful slob who's only fit to live in the mountains, in caves far from civilized people where you won't ever need good manners! Get out of my sight! - Dear Cesario, please don't be offended. - Get out of here, you barbarian!

paragraphs.original:
Exeunt SIR TOBY BELCH, SIR ANDREW, and FABIAN
SIR TOBY BELCH
SIR ANDREW
FABIAN
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH, SIR ANDREW, and FABIAN exit.
SIR TOBY BELCH
SIR ANDREW
FABIAN

paragraphs.original:
I prithee, gentle friend,
Let thy fair wisdom, not thy passion, sway
In this uncivil and unjust extent
Against thy peace. Go with me to my house,
And hear thou there how many fruitless pranks
This ruffian hath botched up, that thou thereby
Mayst smile at this. Thou shalt not choose but go.
Do not deny. Beshrew his soul for me!
He started one poor heart of mine in thee.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, my dear friend, please don't get too upset by these rude people who bothered you. Come with me to my house. I'll tell you about all the pointless, clumsy pranks this thug uncle of mine has come up with, so that you can laugh at this one. You have to come with me. Please don't say no. Damn that Toby! He made my heart leap for you.

paragraphs.original:
SEBASTIAN
(aside) What relish is in this? How runs the stream?
aside
Or I am mad, or else this is a dream.
Let fancy still my sense in Lethe steep.
paragraphs.translated:
SEBASTIAN
(to himself) What does this mean? Where is this all going? Either I'm insane or this is a dream. I hope these
(to himself)

paragraphs.original: If it be thus to dream, still let me sleep!
paragraphs.translated: delusions continue. If this is a dream, let me keep on sleeping!

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Nay, come, I prithee. Would thou'dst be ruled by me!
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Come with me, please. I wish you'd do what I ask!

paragraphs.original:
SEBASTIAN
Madam, I will.
paragraphs.translated:
SEBASTIAN
Madam, I will.

paragraphs.original:
OLIVIA
Oh, say so, and so be!
paragraphs.translated:
OLIVIA
Oh, say it, and mean it!

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original:
Enter MARIA and FOOL
MARIA
FOOL
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA and the FOOL enter.
MARIA
FOOL

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
Nay, I prithee, put on this gown and this beard. Make him believe thou art Sir Topas the curate. Do it quickly. I'll call Sir Toby the whilst.
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
No, I'm telling you, put on this robe and beard. Make him think you're Sir Topas the priest. Be quick. Meanwhile, I'll get Sir Toby.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA exits.
MARIA

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
Well, I'll put it on, and I will dissemble myself in 't, and I would I were the first that ever dissembled in such a gown.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
Well, I'll put it on and disguise myself. I wish I were the first person who ever told lies in a priest's robe.

paragraphs.original:
FOOL puts on gown and beard
FOOL
paragraphs.translated:
The FOOL puts on the robe and beard.
FOOL

paragraphs.original: I am not tall enough to become the function well, nor lean enough to be thought a good student, but to be said an honest man and a good housekeeper goes as fairly as to say a careful man and a great scholar. The competitors enter.
paragraphs.translated: I'm not tall enough to make a believable priest, or skinny enough to look like a good student. But if you're an honest man and a good host, that's almost as good as being moral and studious. Here come the conspirators.

paragraphs.original:
Enter SIR TOBY BELCH and MARIA
SIR TOBY BELCH
MARIA
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH and MARIA enter.
SIR TOBY BELCH
MARIA

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Jove bless thee, master Parson.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
God bless you, Mr. Priest.

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
Bonos dies, Sir Toby. For, as the old hermit of Prague, that never saw pen and ink, very wittily said to a niece of King Gorboduc, "That that is is." So I, being Master Parson, am Master Parson. For, what is "that" but "that," and "is" but "is"?
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
Bonos dies, Sir Toby. As the old hermit of Prague, who couldn't read or write, said very wittily to a niece of King Gorboduc, "Whatever is, is." So since I'm Mr. Priest, I'm Mr. Priest. Because isn't "that" "that," and isn't "is" "is"?
Bonos dies

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
To him, Sir Topas.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Go to him, Sir Topas.

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
(disguising his voice) What ho, I say! Peace in this prison!
disguising his voice
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
(disguising his voice) Quiet down in this prison!
(disguising his voice)

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
The knave counterfeits well. A good knave.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
The fool's a good actor. A good fool.

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
(from within) Who calls there?
from within
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
(offstage) Who's shouting?
(offstage)

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
Sir Topas the curate, who comes to visit Malvolio the lunatic.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
I'm Sir Topas the priest. I've come to visit Malvolio the lunatic.

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
Sir Topas, Sir Topas, good Sir Topas, go to my lady -
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
Sir Topas, Sir Topas, good Sir Topas, please go find my lady Olivia -

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
Out, hyperbolical fiend! How vexest thou this man! Talkest thou nothing but of ladies?
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
Get out, demon! Why are you bothering this poor man! Can't you talk about anything besides ladies?

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(aside) Well said, Master Parson.
aside
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
(to himself) Well said, Mr. Priest.
(to himself)

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
Sir Topas, never was man thus wronged. Good Sir Topas, do not think I am mad. They have laid me here in hideous darkness.
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
Sir Topas, nobody's ever been as badly treated as I've been. Good Sir Topas, don't believe I'm insane, They've shut me up here in horrible darkness.

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
Fie, thou dishonest Satan! I call thee by the most modest terms, for I am one of those gentle ones that will use the devil himself with courtesy. Sayest thou that house is dark?
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
You should be ashamed of yourself, Satan, you liar! I'm being gentle with you, because I'm one of those good-hearted people who are polite to the devil himself. You call this house dark?

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
As hell, Sir Topas.
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
Dark as hell, Sir Topas.

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
Why, it hath bay windows transparent as barricadoes, and the clerestories toward the south-north are as lustrous as ebony. And yet complainest thou of obstruction?
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
But it has bay windows that are as transparent as stone walls, and the upper windows facing south-north are as clear as coal. But you're still complaining of darkness and a bad view?

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
I am not mad, Sir Topas. I say to you this house is dark.
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
I'm not insane, Sir Topas. I'm telling you, this house is dark.

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
Madman, thou errest. I say, there is no darkness but ignorance, in which thou art more puzzled than the Egyptians in their fog.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
You're wrong, you madman. There's no darkness except ignorance, and you're more ignorant than the Egyptians during the plague of fog.

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
I say, this house is as dark as ignorance, though ignorance were as dark as hell. And I say, there was never man thus abused. I am no more mad than you are. Make the trial of it in any constant question.
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
I tell you, this house is as dark as ignorance. And I tell you, no man has ever been treated worse than me. I'm no more insane than you are, and I'll prove it. Ask me any commonsense question.

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
What is the opinion of Pythagoras concerning wildfowl?
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
What was the philosopher Pythagoras's belief about wild birds?

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
That the soul of our grandam might haply inhabit a bird.
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
That our grandmother's soul could end up inhabiting a bird.

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
What thinkest thou of his opinion?
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
What do you think of his belief?

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
I think nobly of the soul, and no way approve his opinion.
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
I respect the soul very much, so I disagree with his belief.

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
Fare thee well. Remain thou still in darkness. Thou shalt hold the opinion of Pythagoras ere I will allow of thy wits, and fear to kill a woodcock lest thou dispossess the soul of thy grandam. Fare thee well.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
Well then, goodbye. Stay in the dark. I'll only admit that you're sane when you agree with Pythagoras and hesitate to kill a bird because it might contain your grandmother's soul. Goodbye.

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
Sir Topas, Sir Topas!
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
Sir Topas, Sir Topas!

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
My most exquisite Sir Topas!
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
The brilliant Sir Topas!

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
Nay, I am for all waters.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
I can do anything!

paragraphs.original:
MARIA
Thou mightst have done this without thy beard and gown.
He sees thee not.
paragraphs.translated:
MARIA
You could've done this without your beard and gown. He couldn't see you.

paragraphs.original:
SIR TOBY BELCH
To him in thine own voice, and bring me word how thou findest him. I would we were well rid of this knavery. If he may be conveniently delivered, I would he were, for I am now so far in offense with my niece that I cannot pursue with any safety this sport to the upshot. Come by and by to my chamber.
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH
Now talk to him in your own voice, and tell me how he is. I wish this trick would be over. If we can find a convenient way to let him go, I want to do it. I'm in so much trouble with my niece that it wouldn't be safe to let this prank go to its conclusion. Come to my room later on.

paragraphs.original:
Exeunt SIR TOBY BELCH and MARIA
SIR TOBY BELCH
MARIA
paragraphs.translated:
SIR TOBY BELCH and MARIA exit.
SIR TOBY BELCH
MARIA

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
(sings in his own voice)
(sings in his own voice)
Hey, Robin, jolly Robin,
Hey, Robin, jolly Robin,
Tell me how thy lady does.
Tell me how thy lady does.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
(he sings in his own voice)
(he sings in his own voice)
Hey, Robin, jolly Robin,
Hey, Robin, jolly Robin,
Tell me how your lady is.
Tell me how your lady is.

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
Fool!
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
Fool!

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
(sings) My lady is unkind, perdy.
(sings) My lady is unkind, perdy.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
(singing) My lady's mean, and that's a fact.
(singing) My lady's mean, and that's a fact.

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
Fool!
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
Fool!

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
(sings) Alas, why is she so?
(sings) Alas, why is she so?
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
(singing) Oh, I'm sorry, why is she mean?
(singing) Oh, I'm sorry, why is she mean?

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
Fool, I say!
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
Fool, I say!

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
(sings) She loves another - Who calls, ha?
(sings) She loves another - Who calls, ha?
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
(singing) She loves someone else - Who's shouting?
(singing) She loves someone else - Who's shouting?

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
Good fool, as ever thou wilt deserve well at my hand, help me to a candle, and pen, ink, and paper. As I am a gentleman, I will live to be thankful to thee for 't.
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
Good fool, good jester, I'll make it worth your while if you get me a candle, and a pen, ink and paper. You have my word as a gentleman that I'll always be grateful to you.

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
Master Malvolio?
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
Master Malvolio?

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
Ay, good fool.
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
Yes, good fool.

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
Alas, sir, how fell you besides your five wits?
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
Poor man, how did you go insane?

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
Fool, there was never a man so notoriously abused: I am as well in my wits, Fool, as thou art.
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
Fool, no one has ever been as mistreated as I am. I'm completely sane, Fool. I'm as sane as you are.

paragraphs.original:
FOOL
But as well? Then you are mad indeed, if you be no better in your wits than a fool.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL
As sane as me? Then you really are insane, if you're no saner than a fool.

paragraphs.original:
MALVOLIO
They have here propertied me, keep me in darkness, send ministers to me - asses! - and do all they can to face me out of my wits.
paragraphs.translated:
MALVOLIO
